text: our journey.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I soon lost sight and recollection of ghostly fears in the beauty of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: scene as we drove along, although had I known the language, or rather
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: languages, which my fellow-passengers were speaking, I might not have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: been able to throw them off so easily. Before us lay a green sloping
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: land full of forests and woods, with here and there steep hills, crowned
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with clumps of trees or with farmhouses, the blank gable end to the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: road. There was everywhere a bewildering mass of fruit blossom--apple,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: plum, pear, cherry; and as we drove by I could see the green grass under
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the trees spangled with the fallen petals. In and out amongst these
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: green hills of what they call here the "Mittel Land" ran the road,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: losing itself as it swept round the grassy curve, or was shut out by the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: straggling ends of pine woods, which here and there ran down the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hillsides like tongues of flame. The road was rugged, but still we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seemed to fly over it with a feverish haste. I could not understand then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: what the haste meant, but the driver was evidently bent on losing no
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: time in reaching Borgo Prund. I was told that this road is in summertime
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: excellent, but that it had not yet been put in order after the winter
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: snows. In this respect it is different from the general run of roads in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the Carpathians, for it is an old tradition that they are not to be kept
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in too good order. Of old the Hospadars would not repair them, lest the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Turk should think that they were preparing to bring in foreign troops,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and so hasten the war which was always really at loading point.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Beyond the green swelling hills of the Mittel Land rose mighty slopes
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of forest up to the lofty steeps of the Carpathians themselves. Right
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and left of us they towered, with the afternoon sun falling full upon
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them and bringing out all the glorious colours of this beautiful range,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: deep blue and purple in the shadows of the peaks, green and brown where
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: grass and rock mingled, and an endless perspective of jagged rock and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pointed crags, till these were themselves lost in the distance, where
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the snowy peaks rose grandly. Here and there seemed mighty rifts in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mountains, through which, as the sun began to sink, we saw now and again
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the white gleam of falling water. One of my companions touched my arm as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we swept round the base of a hill and opened up the lofty, snow-covered
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: peak of a mountain, which seemed, as we wound on our serpentine way, to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be right before us:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Look! Isten szek!"--"God's seat!"--and he crossed himself reverently.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: As we wound on our endless way, and the sun sank lower and lower behind
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: us, the shadows of the evening began to creep round us. This was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: emphasised by the fact that the snowy mountain-top still held the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sunset, and seemed to glow out with a delicate cool pink. Here and there
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we passed Cszeks and Slovaks, all in picturesque attire, but I noticed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that goitre was painfully prevalent. By the roadside were many crosses,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and as we swept by, my companions all crossed themselves. Here and there
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was a peasant man or woman kneeling before a shrine, who did not even
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: turn round as we approached, but seemed in the self-surrender of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: devotion to have neither eyes nor ears for the outer world. There were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: many things new to me: for instance, hay-ricks in the trees, and here
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and there very beautiful masses of weeping birch, their white stems
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shining like silver through the delicate green of the leaves. Now and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: again we passed a leiter-wagon--the ordinary peasant's cart--with its
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: long, snake-like vertebra, calculated to suit the inequalities of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: road. On this were sure to be seated quite a group of home-coming
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: peasants, the Cszeks with their white, and the Slovaks with their
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: coloured, sheepskins, the latter carrying lance-fashion their long
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: staves, with axe at end. As the evening fell it began to get very cold,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and the growing twilight seemed to merge into one dark mistiness the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gloom of the trees, oak, beech, and pine, though in the valleys which
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ran deep between the spurs of the hills, as we ascended through the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Pass, the dark firs stood out here and there against the background of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: late-lying snow. Sometimes, as the road was cut through the pine woods
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that seemed in the darkness to be closing down upon us, great masses of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: greyness, which here and there bestrewed the trees, produced a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: peculiarly weird and solemn effect, which carried on the thoughts and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: grim fancies engendered earlier in the evening, when the falling sunset
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: threw into strange relief the ghost-like clouds which amongst the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Carpathians seem to wind ceaselessly through the valleys. Sometimes the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hills were so steep that, despite our driver's haste, the horses could
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: only go slowly. I wished to get down and walk up them, as we do at home,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but the driver would not hear of it. "No, no," he said; "you must not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: walk here; the dogs are too fierce"; and then he added, with what he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: evidently meant for grim pleasantry--for he looked round to catch the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: approving smile of the rest--"and you may have enough of such matters
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: before you go to sleep." The only stop he would make was a moment's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pause to light his lamps.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: When it grew dark there seemed to be some excitement amongst the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: passengers, and they kept speaking to him, one after the other, as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: though urging him to further speed. He lashed the horses unmercifully
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with his long whip, and with wild cries of encouragement urged them on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to further exertions. Then through the darkness I could see a sort of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: patch of grey light ahead of us, as though there were a cleft in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hills. The excitement of the passengers grew greater; the crazy coach
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rocked on its great leather springs, and swayed like a boat tossed on a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stormy sea. I had to hold on. The road grew more level, and we appeared
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to fly along. Then the mountains seemed to come nearer to us on each
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: side and to frown down upon us; we were entering on the Borgo Pass. One
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: by one several of the passengers offered me gifts, which they pressed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: upon me with an earnestness which would take no denial; these were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: certainly of an odd and varied kind, but each was given in simple good
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: faith, with a kindly word, and a blessing, and that strange mixture of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fear-meaning movements which I had seen outside the hotel at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Bistritz--the sign of the cross and the guard against the evil eye.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Then, as we flew along, the driver leaned forward, and on each side the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: passengers, craning over the edge of the coach, peered eagerly into the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: darkness. It was evident that something very exciting was either
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: happening or expected, but though I asked each passenger, no one would
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: give me the slightest explanation. This state of excitement kept on for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: some little time; and at last we saw before us the Pass opening out on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the eastern side. There were dark, rolling clouds overhead, and in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: air the heavy, oppressive sense of thunder. It seemed as though the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mountain range had separated two atmospheres, and that now we had got
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: into the thunderous one. I was now myself looking out for the conveyance
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: which was to take me to the Count. Each moment I expected to see the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: glare of lamps through the blackness; but all was dark. The only light
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was the flickering rays of our own lamps, in which the steam from our
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hard-driven horses rose in a white cloud. We could see now the sandy
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: road lying white before us, but there was on it no sign of a vehicle.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The passengers drew back with a sigh of gladness, which seemed to mock
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my own disappointment. I was already thinking what I had best do, when
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the driver, looking at his watch, said to the others something which I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could hardly hear, it was spoken so quietly and in so low a tone; I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thought it was "An hour less than the time." Then turning to me, he said
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in German worse than my own:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "There is no carriage here. The Herr is not expected after all. He will
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: now come on to Bukovina, and return to-morrow or the next day; better
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the next day." Whilst he was speaking the horses began to neigh and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: snort and plunge wildly, so that the driver had to hold them up. Then,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: amongst a chorus of screams from the peasants and a universal crossing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of themselves, a calèche, with four horses, drove up behind us, overtook
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: us, and drew up beside the coach. I could see from the flash of our
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lamps, as the rays fell on them, that the horses were coal-black and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: splendid animals. They were driven by a tall man, with a long brown
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: beard and a great black hat, which seemed to hide his face from us. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could only see the gleam of a pair of very bright eyes, which seemed red
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in the lamplight, as he turned to us. He said to the driver:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "You are early to-night, my friend." The man stammered in reply:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "The English Herr was in a hurry," to which the stranger replied:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "That is why, I suppose, you wished him to go on to Bukovina. You cannot
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: deceive me, my friend; I know too much, and my horses are swift." As he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: spoke he smiled, and the lamplight fell on a hard-looking mouth, with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: very red lips and sharp-looking teeth, as white as ivory. One of my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: companions whispered to another the line from Burger's "Lenore":--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Denn die Todten reiten schnell"--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ("For the dead travel fast.")
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The strange driver evidently heard the words, for he looked up with a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gleaming smile. The passenger turned his face away, at the same time
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: putting out his two fingers and crossing himself. "Give me the Herr's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: luggage," said the driver; and with exceeding alacrity my bags were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: handed out and put in the calèche. Then I descended from the side of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: coach, as the calèche was close alongside, the driver helping me with a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hand which caught my arm in a grip of steel; his strength must have been
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: prodigious. Without a word he shook his reins, the horses turned, and we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: swept into the darkness of the Pass. As I looked back I saw the steam
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: from the horses of the coach by the light of the lamps, and projected
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: against it the figures of my late companions crossing themselves. Then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the driver cracked his whip and called to his horses, and off they swept
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: on their way to Bukovina. As they sank into the darkness I felt a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: strange chill, and a lonely feeling came over me; but a cloak was thrown
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: over my shoulders, and a rug across my knees, and the driver said in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: excellent German:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "The night is chill, mein Herr, and my master the Count bade me take all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: care of you. There is a flask of slivovitz (the plum brandy of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: country) underneath the seat, if you should require it." I did not take
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: any, but it was a comfort to know it was there all the same. I felt a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: little strangely, and not a little frightened. I think had there been
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: any alternative I should have taken it, instead of prosecuting that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: unknown night journey. The carriage went at a hard pace straight along,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: then we made a complete turn and went along another straight road. It
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seemed to me that we were simply going over and over the same ground
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: again; and so I took note of some salient point, and found that this was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so. I would have liked to have asked the driver what this all meant, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I really feared to do so, for I thought that, placed as I was, any
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: protest would have had no effect in case there had been an intention to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: delay. By-and-by, however, as I was curious to know how time was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: passing, I struck a match, and by its flame looked at my watch; it was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: within a few minutes of midnight. This gave me a sort of shock, for I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: suppose the general superstition about midnight was increased by my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: recent experiences. I waited with a sick feeling of suspense.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Then a dog began to howl somewhere in a farmhouse far down the road--a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: long, agonised wailing, as if from fear. The sound was taken up by
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: another dog, and then another and another, till, borne on the wind which
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: now sighed softly through the Pass, a wild howling began, which seemed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to come from all over the country, as far as the imagination could grasp
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it through the gloom of the night. At the first howl the horses began to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: strain and rear, but the driver spoke to them soothingly, and they
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quieted down, but shivered and sweated as though after a runaway from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sudden fright. Then, far off in the distance, from the mountains on each
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: side of us began a louder and a sharper howling--that of wolves--which
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: affected both the horses and myself in the same way--for I was minded to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: jump from the calèche and run, whilst they reared again and plunged
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: madly, so that the driver had to use all his great strength to keep them
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: from bolting. In a few minutes, however, my own ears got accustomed to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the sound, and the horses so far became quiet that the driver was able
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to descend and to stand before them. He petted and soothed them, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: whispered something in their ears, as I have heard of horse-tamers
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: doing, and with extraordinary effect, for under his caresses they became
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quite manageable again, though they still trembled. The driver again
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: took his seat, and shaking his reins, started off at a great pace. This
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: time, after going to the far side of the Pass, he suddenly turned down a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: narrow roadway which ran sharply to the right.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Soon we were hemmed in with trees, which in places arched right over the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: roadway till we passed as through a tunnel; and again great frowning
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rocks guarded us boldly on either side. Though we were in shelter, we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could hear the rising wind, for it moaned and whistled through the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rocks, and the branches of the trees crashed together as we swept along.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: It grew colder and colder still, and fine, powdery snow began to fall,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so that soon we and all around us were covered with a white blanket. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: keen wind still carried the howling of the dogs, though this grew
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fainter as we went on our way. The baying of the wolves sounded nearer
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and nearer, as though they were closing round on us from every side. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: grew dreadfully afraid, and the horses shared my fear. The driver,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: however, was not in the least disturbed; he kept turning his head to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: left and right, but I could not see anything through the darkness.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Suddenly, away on our left, I saw a faint flickering blue flame. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: driver saw it at the same moment; he at once checked the horses, and,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: jumping to the ground, disappeared into the darkness. I did not know
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: what to do, the less as the howling of the wolves grew closer; but while
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I wondered the driver suddenly appeared again, and without a word took
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his seat, and we resumed our journey. I think I must have fallen asleep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and kept dreaming of the incident, for it seemed to be repeated
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: endlessly, and now looking back, it is like a sort of awful nightmare.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Once the flame appeared so near the road, that even in the darkness
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: around us I could watch the driver's motions. He went rapidly to where
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the blue flame arose--it must have been very faint, for it did not seem
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to illumine the place around it at all--and gathering a few stones,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: formed them into some device. Once there appeared a strange optical
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: effect: when he stood between me and the flame he did not obstruct it,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for I could see its ghostly flicker all the same. This startled me, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as the effect was only momentary, I took it that my eyes deceived me
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: straining through the darkness. Then for a time there were no blue
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flames, and we sped onwards through the gloom, with the howling of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wolves around us, as though they were following in a moving circle.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: At last there came a time when the driver went further afield than he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had yet gone, and during his absence, the horses began to tremble worse
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: than ever and to snort and scream with fright. I could not see any cause
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for it, for the howling of the wolves had ceased altogether; but just
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: then the moon, sailing through the black clouds, appeared behind the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: jagged crest of a beetling, pine-clad rock, and by its light I saw
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: around us a ring of wolves, with white teeth and lolling red tongues,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with long, sinewy limbs and shaggy hair. They were a hundred times more
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: terrible in the grim silence which held them than even when they howled.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: For myself, I felt a sort of paralysis of fear. It is only when a man
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: feels himself face to face with such horrors that he can understand
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: their true import.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: All at once the wolves began to howl as though the moonlight had had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: some peculiar effect on them. The horses jumped about and reared, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: looked helplessly round with eyes that rolled in a way painful to see;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but the living ring of terror encompassed them on every side; and they
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had perforce to remain within it. I called to the coachman to come, for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it seemed to me that our only chance was to try to break out through the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ring and to aid his approach. I shouted and beat the side of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: calèche, hoping by the noise to scare the wolves from that side, so as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to give him a chance of reaching the trap. How he came there, I know
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not, but I heard his voice raised in a tone of imperious command, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: looking towards the sound, saw him stand in the roadway. As he swept his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: long arms, as though brushing aside some impalpable obstacle, the wolves
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fell back and back further still. Just then a heavy cloud passed across
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the face of the moon, so that we were again in darkness.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: When I could see again the driver was climbing into the calèche, and the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wolves had disappeared. This was all so strange and uncanny that a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dreadful fear came upon me, and I was afraid to speak or move. The time
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seemed interminable as we swept on our way, now in almost complete
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: darkness, for the rolling clouds obscured the moon. We kept on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ascending, with occasional periods of quick descent, but in the main
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: always ascending. Suddenly, I became conscious of the fact that the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: driver was in the act of pulling up the horses in the courtyard of a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: vast ruined castle, from whose tall black windows came no ray of light,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and whose broken battlements showed a jagged line against the moonlit
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sky.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: CHAPTER II
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: JONATHAN HARKER'S JOURNAL--_continued_
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _5 May._--I must have been asleep, for certainly if I had been fully
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: awake I must have noticed the approach of such a remarkable place. In
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the gloom the courtyard looked of considerable size, and as several dark
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ways led from it under great round arches, it perhaps seemed bigger than
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it really is. I have not yet been able to see it by daylight.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: When the calèche stopped, the driver jumped down and held out his hand
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to assist me to alight. Again I could not but notice his prodigious
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: strength. His hand actually seemed like a steel vice that could have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: crushed mine if he had chosen. Then he took out my traps, and placed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them on the ground beside me as I stood close to a great door, old and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: studded with large iron nails, and set in a projecting doorway of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: massive stone. I could see even in the dim light that the stone was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: massively carved, but that the carving had been much worn by time and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: weather. As I stood, the driver jumped again into his seat and shook the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: reins; the horses started forward, and trap and all disappeared down one
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of the dark openings.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I stood in silence where I was, for I did not know what to do. Of bell
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: or knocker there was no sign; through these frowning walls and dark
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: window openings it was not likely that my voice could penetrate. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: time I waited seemed endless, and I felt doubts and fears crowding upon
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me. What sort of place had I come to, and among what kind of people?
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: What sort of grim adventure was it on which I had embarked? Was this a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: customary incident in the life of a solicitor's clerk sent out to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: explain the purchase of a London estate to a foreigner? Solicitor's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: clerk! Mina would not like that. Solicitor--for just before leaving
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: London I got word that my examination was successful; and I am now a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: full-blown solicitor! I began to rub my eyes and pinch myself to see if
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I were awake. It all seemed like a horrible nightmare to me, and I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: expected that I should suddenly awake, and find myself at home, with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the dawn struggling in through the windows, as I had now and again felt
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in the morning after a day of overwork. But my flesh answered the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pinching test, and my eyes were not to be deceived. I was indeed awake
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and among the Carpathians. All I could do now was to be patient, and to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wait the coming of the morning.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Just as I had come to this conclusion I heard a heavy step approaching
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: behind the great door, and saw through the chinks the gleam of a coming
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: light. Then there was the sound of rattling chains and the clanking of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: massive bolts drawn back. A key was turned with the loud grating noise
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of long disuse, and the great door swung back.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Within, stood a tall old man, clean shaven save for a long white
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: moustache, and clad in black from head to foot, without a single speck
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of colour about him anywhere. He held in his hand an antique silver
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lamp, in which the flame burned without chimney or globe of any kind,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: throwing long quivering shadows as it flickered in the draught of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: open door. The old man motioned me in with his right hand with a courtly
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gesture, saying in excellent English, but with a strange intonation:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Welcome to my house! Enter freely and of your own will!" He made no
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: motion of stepping to meet me, but stood like a statue, as though his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gesture of welcome had fixed him into stone. The instant, however, that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I had stepped over the threshold, he moved impulsively forward, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: holding out his hand grasped mine with a strength which made me wince,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: an effect which was not lessened by the fact that it seemed as cold as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ice--more like the hand of a dead than a living man. Again he said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Welcome to my house. Come freely. Go safely; and leave something of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: happiness you bring!" The strength of the handshake was so much akin to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that which I had noticed in the driver, whose face I had not seen, that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for a moment I doubted if it were not the same person to whom I was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: speaking; so to make sure, I said interrogatively:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Count Dracula?" He bowed in a courtly way as he replied:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I am Dracula; and I bid you welcome, Mr. Harker, to my house. Come in;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the night air is chill, and you must need to eat and rest." As he was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: speaking, he put the lamp on a bracket on the wall, and stepping out,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: took my luggage; he had carried it in before I could forestall him. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: protested but he insisted:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Nay, sir, you are my guest. It is late, and my people are not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: available. Let me see to your comfort myself." He insisted on carrying
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my traps along the passage, and then up a great winding stair, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: along another great passage, on whose stone floor our steps rang
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: heavily. At the end of this he threw open a heavy door, and I rejoiced
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to see within a well-lit room in which a table was spread for supper,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and on whose mighty hearth a great fire of logs, freshly replenished,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flamed and flared.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The Count halted, putting down my bags, closed the door, and crossing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the room, opened another door, which led into a small octagonal room lit
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: by a single lamp, and seemingly without a window of any sort. Passing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: through this, he opened another door, and motioned me to enter. It was a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: welcome sight; for here was a great bedroom well lighted and warmed with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: another log fire,--also added to but lately, for the top logs were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fresh--which sent a hollow roar up the wide chimney. The Count himself
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: left my luggage inside and withdrew, saying, before he closed the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: door:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "You will need, after your journey, to refresh yourself by making your
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: toilet. I trust you will find all you wish. When you are ready, come
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: into the other room, where you will find your supper prepared."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The light and warmth and the Count's courteous welcome seemed to have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dissipated all my doubts and fears. Having then reached my normal state,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I discovered that I was half famished with hunger; so making a hasty
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: toilet, I went into the other room.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I found supper already laid out. My host, who stood on one side of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: great fireplace, leaning against the stonework, made a graceful wave of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his hand to the table, and said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I pray you, be seated and sup how you please. You will, I trust, excuse
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me that I do not join you; but I have dined already, and I do not sup."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I handed to him the sealed letter which Mr. Hawkins had entrusted to me.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: He opened it and read it gravely; then, with a charming smile, he handed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it to me to read. One passage of it, at least, gave me a thrill of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pleasure.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I must regret that an attack of gout, from which malady I am a constant
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sufferer, forbids absolutely any travelling on my part for some time to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: come; but I am happy to say I can send a sufficient substitute, one in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: whom I have every possible confidence. He is a young man, full of energy
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and talent in his own way, and of a very faithful disposition. He is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: discreet and silent, and has grown into manhood in my service. He shall
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be ready to attend on you when you will during his stay, and shall take
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: your instructions in all matters."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The Count himself came forward and took off the cover of a dish, and I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fell to at once on an excellent roast chicken. This, with some cheese
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and a salad and a bottle of old Tokay, of which I had two glasses, was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my supper. During the time I was eating it the Count asked me many
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: questions as to my journey, and I told him by degrees all I had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: experienced.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: By this time I had finished my supper, and by my host's desire had drawn
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: up a chair by the fire and begun to smoke a cigar which he offered me,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: at the same time excusing himself that he did not smoke. I had now an
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: opportunity of observing him, and found him of a very marked
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: physiognomy.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: His face was a strong--a very strong--aquiline, with high bridge of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thin nose and peculiarly arched nostrils; with lofty domed forehead, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hair growing scantily round the temples but profusely elsewhere. His
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: eyebrows were very massive, almost meeting over the nose, and with bushy
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hair that seemed to curl in its own profusion. The mouth, so far as I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could see it under the heavy moustache, was fixed and rather
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cruel-looking, with peculiarly sharp white teeth; these protruded over
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the lips, whose remarkable ruddiness showed astonishing vitality in a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: man of his years. For the rest, his ears were pale, and at the tops
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: extremely pointed; the chin was broad and strong, and the cheeks firm
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: though thin. The general effect was one of extraordinary pallor.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Hitherto I had noticed the backs of his hands as they lay on his knees
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in the firelight, and they had seemed rather white and fine; but seeing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them now close to me, I could not but notice that they were rather
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: coarse--broad, with squat fingers. Strange to say, there were hairs in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the centre of the palm. The nails were long and fine, and cut to a sharp
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: point. As the Count leaned over me and his hands touched me, I could not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: repress a shudder. It may have been that his breath was rank, but a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: horrible feeling of nausea came over me, which, do what I would, I could
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not conceal. The Count, evidently noticing it, drew back; and with a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: grim sort of smile, which showed more than he had yet done his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: protuberant teeth, sat himself down again on his own side of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fireplace. We were both silent for a while; and as I looked towards the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: window I saw the first dim streak of the coming dawn. There seemed a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: strange stillness over everything; but as I listened I heard as if from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: down below in the valley the howling of many wolves. The Count's eyes
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gleamed, and he said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Listen to them--the children of the night. What music they make!"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Seeing, I suppose, some expression in my face strange to him, he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: added:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Ah, sir, you dwellers in the city cannot enter into the feelings of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hunter." Then he rose and said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "But you must be tired. Your bedroom is all ready, and to-morrow you
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shall sleep as late as you will. I have to be away till the afternoon;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so sleep well and dream well!" With a courteous bow, he opened for me
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: himself the door to the octagonal room, and I entered my bedroom....
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I am all in a sea of wonders. I doubt; I fear; I think strange things,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: which I dare not confess to my own soul. God keep me, if only for the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sake of those dear to me!
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _7 May._--It is again early morning, but I have rested and enjoyed the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: last twenty-four hours. I slept till late in the day, and awoke of my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: own accord. When I had dressed myself I went into the room where we had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: supped, and found a cold breakfast laid out, with coffee kept hot by the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pot being placed on the hearth. There was a card on the table, on which
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was written:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I have to be absent for a while. Do not wait for me.--D." I set to and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: enjoyed a hearty meal. When I had done, I looked for a bell, so that I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: might let the servants know I had finished; but I could not find one.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: There are certainly odd deficiencies in the house, considering the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: extraordinary evidences of wealth which are round me. The table service
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is of gold, and so beautifully wrought that it must be of immense value.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The curtains and upholstery of the chairs and sofas and the hangings of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my bed are of the costliest and most beautiful fabrics, and must have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: been of fabulous value when they were made, for they are centuries old,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: though in excellent order. I saw something like them in Hampton Court,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but there they were worn and frayed and moth-eaten. But still in none of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the rooms is there a mirror. There is not even a toilet glass on my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: table, and I had to get the little shaving glass from my bag before I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could either shave or brush my hair. I have not yet seen a servant
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: anywhere, or heard a sound near the castle except the howling of wolves.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Some time after I had finished my meal--I do not know whether to call it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: breakfast or dinner, for it was between five and six o'clock when I had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it--I looked about for something to read, for I did not like to go about
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the castle until I had asked the Count's permission. There was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: absolutely nothing in the room, book, newspaper, or even writing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: materials; so I opened another door in the room and found a sort of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: library. The door opposite mine I tried, but found it locked.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: In the library I found, to my great delight, a vast number of English
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: books, whole shelves full of them, and bound volumes of magazines and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: newspapers. A table in the centre was littered with English magazines
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and newspapers, though none of them were of very recent date. The books
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: were of the most varied kind--history, geography, politics, political
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: economy, botany, geology, law--all relating to England and English life
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and customs and manners. There were even such books of reference as the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: London Directory, the "Red" and "Blue" books, Whitaker's Almanac, the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Army and Navy Lists, and--it somehow gladdened my heart to see it--the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Law List.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Whilst I was looking at the books, the door opened, and the Count
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: entered. He saluted me in a hearty way, and hoped that I had had a good
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night's rest. Then he went on:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I am glad you found your way in here, for I am sure there is much that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: will interest you. These companions"--and he laid his hand on some of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the books--"have been good friends to me, and for some years past, ever
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: since I had the idea of going to London, have given me many, many hours
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of pleasure. Through them I have come to know your great England; and to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: know her is to love her. I long to go through the crowded streets of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: your mighty London, to be in the midst of the whirl and rush of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: humanity, to share its life, its change, its death, and all that makes
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it what it is. But alas! as yet I only know your tongue through books.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: To you, my friend, I look that I know it to speak."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "But, Count," I said, "you know and speak English thoroughly!" He bowed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gravely.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I thank you, my friend, for your all too-flattering estimate, but yet I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fear that I am but a little way on the road I would travel. True, I know
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the grammar and the words, but yet I know not how to speak them."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Indeed," I said, "you speak excellently."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Not so," he answered. "Well, I know that, did I move and speak in your
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: London, none there are who would not know me for a stranger. That is not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: enough for me. Here I am noble; I am _boyar_; the common people know me,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and I am master. But a stranger in a strange land, he is no one; men
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: know him not--and to know not is to care not for. I am content if I am
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: like the rest, so that no man stops if he see me, or pause in his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: speaking if he hear my words, 'Ha, ha! a stranger!' I have been so long
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: master that I would be master still--or at least that none other should
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be master of me. You come to me not alone as agent of my friend Peter
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Hawkins, of Exeter, to tell me all about my new estate in London. You
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shall, I trust, rest here with me awhile, so that by our talking I may
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: learn the English intonation; and I would that you tell me when I make
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: error, even of the smallest, in my speaking. I am sorry that I had to be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: away so long to-day; but you will, I know, forgive one who has so many
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: important affairs in hand."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Of course I said all I could about being willing, and asked if I might
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: come into that room when I chose. He answered: "Yes, certainly," and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: added:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "You may go anywhere you wish in the castle, except where the doors are
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: locked, where of course you will not wish to go. There is reason that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all things are as they are, and did you see with my eyes and know with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my knowledge, you would perhaps better understand." I said I was sure of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this, and then he went on:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "We are in Transylvania; and Transylvania is not England. Our ways are
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not your ways, and there shall be to you many strange things. Nay, from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: what you have told me of your experiences already, you know something of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: what strange things there may be."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: This led to much conversation; and as it was evident that he wanted to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: talk, if only for talking's sake, I asked him many questions regarding
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: things that had already happened to me or come within my notice.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Sometimes he sheered off the subject, or turned the conversation by
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pretending not to understand; but generally he answered all I asked most
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: frankly. Then as time went on, and I had got somewhat bolder, I asked
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: him of some of the strange things of the preceding night, as, for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: instance, why the coachman went to the places where he had seen the blue
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flames. He then explained to me that it was commonly believed that on a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: certain night of the year--last night, in fact, when all evil spirits
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: are supposed to have unchecked sway--a blue flame is seen over any place
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: where treasure has been concealed. "That treasure has been hidden," he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: went on, "in the region through which you came last night, there can be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but little doubt; for it was the ground fought over for centuries by the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Wallachian, the Saxon, and the Turk. Why, there is hardly a foot of soil
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in all this region that has not been enriched by the blood of men,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: patriots or invaders. In old days there were stirring times, when the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Austrian and the Hungarian came up in hordes, and the patriots went out
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to meet them--men and women, the aged and the children too--and waited
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: their coming on the rocks above the passes, that they might sweep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: destruction on them with their artificial avalanches. When the invader
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was triumphant he found but little, for whatever there was had been
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sheltered in the friendly soil."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "But how," said I, "can it have remained so long undiscovered, when
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: there is a sure index to it if men will but take the trouble to look?"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The Count smiled, and as his lips ran back over his gums, the long,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sharp, canine teeth showed out strangely; he answered:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Because your peasant is at heart a coward and a fool! Those flames only
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: appear on one night; and on that night no man of this land will, if he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: can help it, stir without his doors. And, dear sir, even if he did he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: would not know what to do. Why, even the peasant that you tell me of who
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: marked the place of the flame would not know where to look in daylight
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: even for his own work. Even you would not, I dare be sworn, be able to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: find these places again?"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "There you are right," I said. "I know no more than the dead where even
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to look for them." Then we drifted into other matters.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Come," he said at last, "tell me of London and of the house which you
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have procured for me." With an apology for my remissness, I went into my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: own room to get the papers from my bag. Whilst I was placing them in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: order I heard a rattling of china and silver in the next room, and as I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: passed through, noticed that the table had been cleared and the lamp
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lit, for it was by this time deep into the dark. The lamps were also lit
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in the study or library, and I found the Count lying on the sofa,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: reading, of all things in the world, an English Bradshaw's Guide. When I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: came in he cleared the books and papers from the table; and with him I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: went into plans and deeds and figures of all sorts. He was interested in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: everything, and asked me a myriad questions about the place and its
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: surroundings. He clearly had studied beforehand all he could get on the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: subject of the neighbourhood, for he evidently at the end knew very much
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: more than I did. When I remarked this, he answered:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Well, but, my friend, is it not needful that I should? When I go there
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I shall be all alone, and my friend Harker Jonathan--nay, pardon me, I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fall into my country's habit of putting your patronymic first--my friend
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Jonathan Harker will not be by my side to correct and aid me. He will be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in Exeter, miles away, probably working at papers of the law with my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: other friend, Peter Hawkins. So!"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: We went thoroughly into the business of the purchase of the estate at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Purfleet. When I had told him the facts and got his signature to the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: necessary papers, and had written a letter with them ready to post to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Mr. Hawkins, he began to ask me how I had come across so suitable a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: place. I read to him the notes which I had made at the time, and which I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: inscribe here:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "At Purfleet, on a by-road, I came across just such a place as seemed to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be required, and where was displayed a dilapidated notice that the place
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was for sale. It is surrounded by a high wall, of ancient structure,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: built of heavy stones, and has not been repaired for a large number of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: years. The closed gates are of heavy old oak and iron, all eaten with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rust.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "The estate is called Carfax, no doubt a corruption of the old _Quatre
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Face_, as the house is four-sided, agreeing with the cardinal points of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the compass. It contains in all some twenty acres, quite surrounded by
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the solid stone wall above mentioned. There are many trees on it, which
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: make it in places gloomy, and there is a deep, dark-looking pond or
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: small lake, evidently fed by some springs, as the water is clear and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flows away in a fair-sized stream. The house is very large and of all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: periods back, I should say, to mediæval times, for one part is of stone
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: immensely thick, with only a few windows high up and heavily barred with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: iron. It looks like part of a keep, and is close to an old chapel or
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: church. I could not enter it, as I had not the key of the door leading
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to it from the house, but I have taken with my kodak views of it from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: various points. The house has been added to, but in a very straggling
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: way, and I can only guess at the amount of ground it covers, which must
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be very great. There are but few houses close at hand, one being a very
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: large house only recently added to and formed into a private lunatic
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: asylum. It is not, however, visible from the grounds."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: When I had finished, he said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I am glad that it is old and big. I myself am of an old family, and to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: live in a new house would kill me. A house cannot be made habitable in a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: day; and, after all, how few days go to make up a century. I rejoice
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: also that there is a chapel of old times. We Transylvanian nobles love
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not to think that our bones may lie amongst the common dead. I seek not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gaiety nor mirth, not the bright voluptuousness of much sunshine and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sparkling waters which please the young and gay. I am no longer young;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and my heart, through weary years of mourning over the dead, is not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: attuned to mirth. Moreover, the walls of my castle are broken; the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shadows are many, and the wind breathes cold through the broken
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: battlements and casements. I love the shade and the shadow, and would
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be alone with my thoughts when I may." Somehow his words and his look
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: did not seem to accord, or else it was that his cast of face made his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: smile look malignant and saturnine.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Presently, with an excuse, he left me, asking me to put all my papers
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: together. He was some little time away, and I began to look at some of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the books around me. One was an atlas, which I found opened naturally at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: England, as if that map had been much used. On looking at it I found in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: certain places little rings marked, and on examining these I noticed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that one was near London on the east side, manifestly where his new
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: estate was situated; the other two were Exeter, and Whitby on the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Yorkshire coast.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: It was the better part of an hour when the Count returned. "Aha!" he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: said; "still at your books? Good! But you must not work always. Come; I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the next room, where I found an excellent supper ready on the table. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: home. But he sat as on the previous night, and chatted whilst I ate.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: After supper I smoked, as on the last evening, and the Count stayed with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me, chatting and asking questions on every conceivable subject, hour
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: after hour. I felt that it was getting very late indeed, but I did not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: say anything, for I felt under obligation to meet my host's wishes in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: every way. I was not sleepy, as the long sleep yesterday had fortified
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me; but I could not help experiencing that chill which comes over one at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the coming of the dawn, which is like, in its way, the turn of the tide.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: They say that people who are near death die generally at the change to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the dawn or at the turn of the tide; any one who has when tired, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: with preternatural shrillness through the clear morning air; Count
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Why, there is the morning again! How remiss I am to let you stay up so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: long. You must make your conversation regarding my dear new country of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: England less interesting, so that I may not forget how time flies by
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: us," and, with a courtly bow, he quickly left me.

text: I went into my own room and drew the curtains, but there was little to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: notice; my window opened into the courtyard, all I could see was the

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: _8 May._--I began to fear as I wrote in this book that I was getting too
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: diffuse; but now I am glad that I went into detail from the first, for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: there is something so strange about this place and all in it that I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cannot but feel uneasy. I wish I were safe out of it, or that I had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: never come. It may be that this strange night-existence is telling on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me; but would that that were all! If there were any one to talk to I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could bear it, but there is no one. I have only the Count to speak with,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and he!--I fear I am myself the only living soul within the place. Let
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me be prosaic so far as facts can be; it will help me to bear up, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: imagination must not run riot with me. If it does I am lost. Let me say
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: at once how I stand--or seem to.
author: Stoker, Bram

text: I only slept a few hours when I went to bed, and feeling that I could
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

text: This time there could be no error, for the man was close to me, and I

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula
