author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: When I found that I was a prisoner a sort of wild feeling came over me.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I rushed up and down the stairs, trying every door and peering out of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: every window I could find; but after a little the conviction of my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: helplessness overpowered all other feelings. When I look back after a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: few hours I think I must have been mad for the time, for I behaved much
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as a rat does in a trap. When, however, the conviction had come to me
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that I was helpless I sat down quietly--as quietly as I have ever done
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: anything in my life--and began to think over what was best to be done. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: am thinking still, and as yet have come to no definite conclusion. Of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: one thing only am I certain; that it is no use making my ideas known to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the Count. He knows well that I am imprisoned; and as he has done it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: himself, and has doubtless his own motives for it, he would only deceive
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me if I trusted him fully with the facts. So far as I can see, my only
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: plan will be to keep my knowledge and my fears to myself, and my eyes
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: open. I am, I know, either being deceived, like a baby, by my own fears,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: or else I am in desperate straits; and if the latter be so, I need, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shall need, all my brains to get through.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thought--that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hand in silence. How was it that all the people at Bistritz and on the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mind about it. In the meantime I must find out all I can about Count
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Dracula, as it may help me to understand. To-night he may talk of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: himself, if I turn the conversation that way. I must be very careful,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: however, not to awake his suspicion.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Midnight._--I have had a long talk with the Count. I asked him a few
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: questions on Transylvania history, and he warmed up to the subject
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wonderfully. In his speaking of things and people, and especially of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: battles, he spoke as if he had been present at them all. This he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: afterwards explained by saying that to a _boyar_ the pride of his house
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and name is his own pride, that their glory is his glory, that their
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fate is his fate. Whenever he spoke of his house he always said "we,"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and spoke almost in the plural, like a king speaking. I wish I could put
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: down all he said exactly as he said it, for to me it was most
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fascinating. It seemed to have in it a whole history of the country. He
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: grew excited as he spoke, and walked about the room pulling his great
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: white moustache and grasping anything on which he laid his hands as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: though he would crush it by main strength. One thing he said which I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shall put down as nearly as I can; for it tells in its way the story of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his race:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "We Szekelys have a right to be proud, for in our veins flows the blood
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of many brave races who fought as the lion fights, for lordship. Here,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in the whirlpool of European races, the Ugric tribe bore down from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Iceland the fighting spirit which Thor and Wodin gave them, which their
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Berserkers displayed to such fell intent on the seaboards of Europe, ay,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and of Asia and Africa too, till the peoples thought that the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: were-wolves themselves had come. Here, too, when they came, they found
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the Huns, whose warlike fury had swept the earth like a living flame,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: till the dying peoples held that in their veins ran the blood of those
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: old witches, who, expelled from Scythia had mated with the devils in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: desert. Fools, fools! What devil or what witch was ever so great as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Attila, whose blood is in these veins?" He held up his arms. "Is it a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wonder that we were a conquering race; that we were proud; that when the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Magyar, the Lombard, the Avar, the Bulgar, or the Turk poured his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thousands on our frontiers, we drove them back? Is it strange that when
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Arpad and his legions swept through the Hungarian fatherland he found us
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: here when he reached the frontier; that the Honfoglalas was completed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: there? And when the Hungarian flood swept eastward, the Szekelys were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: claimed as kindred by the victorious Magyars, and to us for centuries
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was trusted the guarding of the frontier of Turkey-land; ay, and more
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: than that, endless duty of the frontier guard, for, as the Turks say,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: 'water sleeps, and enemy is sleepless.' Who more gladly than we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: throughout the Four Nations received the 'bloody sword,' or at its
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: warlike call flocked quicker to the standard of the King? When was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: redeemed that great shame of my nation, the shame of Cassova, when the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flags of the Wallach and the Magyar went down beneath the Crescent? Who
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was it but one of my own race who as Voivode crossed the Danube and beat
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the Turk on his own ground? This was a Dracula indeed! Woe was it that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his own unworthy brother, when he had fallen, sold his people to the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Turk and brought the shame of slavery on them! Was it not this Dracula,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: indeed, who inspired that other of his race who in a later age again and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: again brought his forces over the great river into Turkey-land; who,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: when he was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though he had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to come alone from the bloody field where his troops were being
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: slaughtered, since he knew that he alone could ultimately triumph! They
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: said that he thought only of himself. Bah! what good are peasants
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: without a leader? Where ends the war without a brain and heart to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: conduct it? Again, when, after the battle of Mohács, we threw off the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Hungarian yoke, we of the Dracula blood were amongst their leaders, for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: our spirit would not brook that we were not free. Ah, young sir, the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Szekelys--and the Dracula as their heart's blood, their brains, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: their swords--can boast a record that mushroom growths like the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Hapsburgs and the Romanoffs can never reach. The warlike days are over.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Blood is too precious a thing in these days of dishonourable peace; and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the glories of the great races are as a tale that is told."

text: _12 May._--Let me begin with facts--bare, meagre facts, verified by
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: books and figures, and of which there can be no doubt. I must not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: confuse them with experiences which will have to rest on my own
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: observation, or my memory of them. Last evening when the Count came from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his room he began by asking me questions on legal matters and on the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: doing of certain kinds of business. I had spent the day wearily over
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: books, and, simply to keep my mind occupied, went over some of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: matters I had been examining at Lincoln's Inn. There was a certain
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: method in the Count's inquiries, so I shall try to put them down in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sequence; the knowledge may somehow or some time be useful to me.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: First, he asked if a man in England might have two solicitors or more. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: told him he might have a dozen if he wished, but that it would not be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wise to have more than one solicitor engaged in one transaction, as only
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: one could act at a time, and that to change would be certain to militate
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: against his interest. He seemed thoroughly to understand, and went on to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ask if there would be any practical difficulty in having one man to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: attend, say, to banking, and another to look after shipping, in case
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: local help were needed in a place far from the home of the banking
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: solicitor. I asked him to explain more fully, so that I might not by any
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: chance mislead him, so he said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I shall illustrate. Your friend and mine, Mr. Peter Hawkins, from under
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the shadow of your beautiful cathedral at Exeter, which is far from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: London, buys for me through your good self my place at London. Good! Now
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: here let me say frankly, lest you should think it strange that I have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sought the services of one so far off from London instead of some one
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: resident there, that my motive was that no local interest might be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: served save my wish only; and as one of London residence might, perhaps,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have some purpose of himself or friend to serve, I went thus afield to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seek my agent, whose labours should be only to my interest. Now, suppose
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I, who have much of affairs, wish to ship goods, say, to Newcastle, or
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Durham, or Harwich, or Dover, might it not be that it could with more
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ease be done by consigning to one in these ports?" I answered that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: certainly it would be most easy, but that we solicitors had a system of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: agency one for the other, so that local work could be done locally on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: instruction from any solicitor, so that the client, simply placing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: himself in the hands of one man, could have his wishes carried out by
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: him without further trouble.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "But," said he, "I could be at liberty to direct myself. Is it not so?"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Of course," I replied; and "such is often done by men of business, who
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: do not like the whole of their affairs to be known by any one person."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Good!" he said, and then went on to ask about the means of making
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: consignments and the forms to be gone through, and of all sorts of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: difficulties which might arise, but by forethought could be guarded
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: against. I explained all these things to him to the best of my ability,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and he certainly left me under the impression that he would have made a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wonderful solicitor, for there was nothing that he did not think of or
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: foresee. For a man who was never in the country, and who did not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: evidently do much in the way of business, his knowledge and acumen were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wonderful. When he had satisfied himself on these points of which he had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: spoken, and I had verified all as well as I could by the books
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: available, he suddenly stood up and said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Have you written since your first letter to our friend Mr. Peter
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Hawkins, or to any other?" It was with some bitterness in my heart that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I answered that I had not, that as yet I had not seen any opportunity of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sending letters to anybody.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shoulder: "write to our friend and to any other; and say, if it will
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: please you, that you shall stay with me until a month from now."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Do you wish me to stay so long?" I asked, for my heart grew cold at the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thought.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: employer, what you will, engaged that someone should come on his behalf,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it was understood that my needs only were to be consulted. I have not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stinted. Is it not so?"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: What could I do but bow acceptance? It was Mr. Hawkins's interest, not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mine, and I had to think of him, not myself; and besides, while Count
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: which made me remember that I was a prisoner, and that if I wished it I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could have no choice. The Count saw his victory in my bow, and his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mastery in the trouble of my face, for he began at once to use them, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in his own smooth, resistless way:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: other than business in your letters. It will doubtless please your
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: friends to know that you are well, and that you look forward to getting
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: home to them. Is it not so?" As he spoke he handed me three sheets of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: post, and looking at them, then at him, and noticing his quiet smile,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with the sharp, canine teeth lying over the red underlip, I understood
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as well as if he had spoken that I should be careful what I wrote, for

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: I could.

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: am reduced. Safety and the assurance of safety are things of the past.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: the lashes. The girl went on her knees, and bent over me, simply

title: Dracula

text: gloating. There was a deliberate voluptuousness which was both thrilling

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: heart.

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with work. The life of an assistant schoolmistress is sometimes trying.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I am longing to be with you, and by the sea, where we can talk together
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: freely and build our castles in the air. I have been working very hard
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lately, because I want to keep up with Jonathan's studies, and I have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: been practising shorthand very assiduously. When we are married I shall
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be able to be useful to Jonathan, and if I can stenograph well enough I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: can take down what he wants to say in this way and write it out for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: him on the typewriter, at which also I am practising very hard. He
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and I sometimes write letters in shorthand, and he is keeping a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stenographic journal of his travels abroad. When I am with you I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shall keep a diary in the same way. I don't mean one of those
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: two-pages-to-the-week-with-Sunday-squeezed-in-a-corner diaries, but a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sort of journal which I can write in whenever I feel inclined. I do not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: suppose there will be much of interest to other people; but it is not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: intended for them. I may show it to Jonathan some day if there is in it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: anything worth sharing, but it is really an exercise book. I shall try
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to do what I see lady journalists do: interviewing and writing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: descriptions and trying to remember conversations. I am told that, with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a little practice, one can remember all that goes on or that one hears
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: said during a day. However, we shall see. I will tell you of my little
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: plans when we meet. I have just had a few hurried lines from Jonathan
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: from Transylvania. He is well, and will be returning in about a week. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: am longing to hear all his news. It must be so nice to see strange
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: countries. I wonder if we--I mean Jonathan and I--shall ever see them
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: together. There is the ten o'clock bell ringing. Good-bye.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Your loving
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "MINA.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Tell me all the news when you write. You have not told me anything for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a long time. I hear rumours, and especially of a tall, handsome,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: curly-haired man???"
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "_17, Chatham Street_,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "_Wednesday_.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "My dearest Mina,--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I must say you tax me _very_ unfairly with being a bad correspondent. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wrote to you _twice_ since we parted, and your last letter was only your
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _second_. Besides, I have nothing to tell you. There is really nothing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to interest you. Town is very pleasant just now, and we go a good deal
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to picture-galleries and for walks and rides in the park. As to the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: tall, curly-haired man, I suppose it was the one who was with me at the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: last Pop. Some one has evidently been telling tales. That was Mr.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Holmwood. He often comes to see us, and he and mamma get on very well
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: together; they have so many things to talk about in common. We met some
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: time ago a man that would just _do for you_, if you were not already
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: engaged to Jonathan. He is an excellent _parti_, being handsome, well
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: off, and of good birth. He is a doctor and really clever. Just fancy! He
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is only nine-and-twenty, and he has an immense lunatic asylum all under
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his own care. Mr. Holmwood introduced him to me, and he called here to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: see us, and often comes now. I think he is one of the most resolute men
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I ever saw, and yet the most calm. He seems absolutely imperturbable. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: can fancy what a wonderful power he must have over his patients. He has
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a curious habit of looking one straight in the face, as if trying to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: read one's thoughts. He tries this on very much with me, but I flatter
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: myself he has got a tough nut to crack. I know that from my glass. Do
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: you ever try to read your own face? _I do_, and I can tell you it is not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a bad study, and gives you more trouble than you can well fancy if you
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have never tried it. He says that I afford him a curious psychological
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: study, and I humbly think I do. I do not, as you know, take sufficient
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: interest in dress to be able to describe the new fashions. Dress is a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: bore. That is slang again, but never mind; Arthur says that every day.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: There, it is all out. Mina, we have told all our secrets to each other
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: since we were _children_; we have slept together and eaten together, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: laughed and cried together; and now, though I have spoken, I would like
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to speak more. Oh, Mina, couldn't you guess? I love him. I am blushing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as I write, for although I _think_ he loves me, he has not told me so in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: words. But oh, Mina, I love him; I love him; I love him! There, that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: does me good. I wish I were with you, dear, sitting by the fire
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: undressing, as we used to sit; and I would try to tell you what I feel.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I do not know how I am writing this even to you. I am afraid to stop,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: or I should tear up the letter, and I don't want to stop, for I _do_ so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: want to tell you all. Let me hear from you _at once_, and tell me all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that you think about it. Mina, I must stop. Good-night. Bless me in your
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: prayers; and, Mina, pray for my happiness.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "LUCY.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "P.S.--I need not tell you this is a secret. Good-night again.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Letter, Lucy Westenra to Mina Murray_.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "My dearest Mina,--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Thanks, and thanks, and thanks again for your sweet letter. It was so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: nice to be able to tell you and to have your sympathy.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "My dear, it never rains but it pours. How true the old proverbs are.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Here am I, who shall be twenty in September, and yet I never had a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: proposal till to-day, not a real proposal, and to-day I have had three.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Just fancy! THREE proposals in one day! Isn't it awful! I feel sorry,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: really and truly sorry, for two of the poor fellows. Oh, Mina, I am so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: happy that I don't know what to do with myself. And three proposals!
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: But, for goodness' sake, don't tell any of the girls, or they would be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: getting all sorts of extravagant ideas and imagining themselves injured
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and slighted if in their very first day at home they did not get six at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: least. Some girls are so vain! You and I, Mina dear, who are engaged and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: are going to settle down soon soberly into old married women, can
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: despise vanity. Well, I must tell you about the three, but you must keep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it a secret, dear, from _every one_, except, of course, Jonathan. You
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: will tell him, because I would, if I were in your place, certainly tell
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Arthur. A woman ought to tell her husband everything--don't you think
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so, dear?--and I must be fair. Men like women, certainly their wives, to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be quite as fair as they are; and women, I am afraid, are not always
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quite as fair as they should be. Well, my dear, number One came just
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: before lunch. I told you of him, Dr. John Seward, the lunatic-asylum
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: man, with the strong jaw and the good forehead. He was very cool
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: outwardly, but was nervous all the same. He had evidently been schooling
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: himself as to all sorts of little things, and remembered them; but he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: almost managed to sit down on his silk hat, which men don't generally do
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: when they are cool, and then when he wanted to appear at ease he kept
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: playing with a lancet in a way that made me nearly scream. He spoke to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me, Mina, very straightforwardly. He told me how dear I was to him,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: though he had known me so little, and what his life would be with me to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: help and cheer him. He was going to tell me how unhappy he would be if I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: did not care for him, but when he saw me cry he said that he was a brute
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and would not add to my present trouble. Then he broke off and asked if
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I could love him in time; and when I shook my head his hands trembled,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and then with some hesitation he asked me if I cared already for any one
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: else. He put it very nicely, saying that he did not want to wring my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: confidence from me, but only to know, because if a woman's heart was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: free a man might have hope. And then, Mina, I felt a sort of duty to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: tell him that there was some one. I only told him that much, and then he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stood up, and he looked very strong and very grave as he took both my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hands in his and said he hoped I would be happy, and that if I ever
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wanted a friend I must count him one of my best. Oh, Mina dear, I can't
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: help crying: and you must excuse this letter being all blotted. Being
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: proposed to is all very nice and all that sort of thing, but it isn't at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all a happy thing when you have to see a poor fellow, whom you know
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: loves you honestly, going away and looking all broken-hearted, and to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: know that, no matter what he may say at the moment, you are passing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quite out of his life. My dear, I must stop here at present, I feel so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: miserable, though I am so happy.
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: off, so I can go on telling you about the day. Well, my dear, number Two
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he looks so young and so fresh that it seems almost impossible that he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: has been to so many places and has had such adventures. I sympathise
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with poor Desdemona when she had such a dangerous stream poured in her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ear, even by a black man. I suppose that we women are such cowards that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we think a man will save us from fears, and we marry him. I know now
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: what I would do if I were a man and wanted to make a girl love me. No, I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: don't, for there was Mr. Morris telling us his stories, and Arthur never
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: told any, and yet---- My dear, I am somewhat previous. Mr. Quincey P.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Morris found me alone. It seems that a man always does find a girl
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: alone. No, he doesn't, for Arthur tried twice to _make_ a chance, and I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: helping him all I could; I am not ashamed to say it now. I must tell you
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: beforehand that Mr. Morris doesn't always speak slang--that is to say,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he never does so to strangers or before them, for he is really well
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to hear him talk American slang, and whenever I was present, and there
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was no one to be shocked, he said such funny things. I am afraid, my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dear, he has to invent it all, for it fits exactly into whatever else he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: has to say. But this is a way slang has. I do not know myself if I shall
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ever speak slang; I do not know if Arthur likes it, as I have never
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: heard him use any as yet. Well, Mr. Morris sat down beside me and looked
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as happy and jolly as he could, but I could see all the same that he was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: very nervous. He took my hand in his, and said ever so sweetly:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "'Miss Lucy, I know I ain't good enough to regulate the fixin's of your
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: little shoes, but I guess if you wait till you find a man that is you
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: will go join them seven young women with the lamps when you quit. Won't
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: you just hitch up alongside of me and let us go down the long road
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: together, driving in double harness?'
author: Stoker, Bram

text: "Well, he did look so good-humoured and so jolly that it didn't seem
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: half so hard to refuse him as it did poor Dr. Seward; so I said, as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lightly as I could, that I did not know anything of hitching, and that I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wasn't broken to harness at all yet. Then he said that he had spoken in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a light manner, and he hoped that if he had made a mistake in doing so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: on so grave, so momentous, an occasion for him, I would forgive him. He
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flirt--though I couldn't help feeling a sort of exultation that he was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: number two in one day. And then, my dear, before I could say a word he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: began pouring out a perfect torrent of love-making, laying his very

title: Dracula

text: heart and soul at my feet. He looked so earnest over it that I shall

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: "'Lucy, you are an honest-hearted girl, I know. I should not be here
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: speaking to you as I am now if I did not believe you clean grit, right
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: through to the very depths of your soul. Tell me, like one good fellow
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to another, is there any one else that you care for? And if there is

title: Dracula

text: I'll never trouble you a hair's breadth again, but will be, if you will
author: Stoker, Bram

text: let me, a very faithful friend.'
author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: _5 June._--The case of Renfield grows more interesting the more I get to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: understand the man. He has certain qualities very largely developed;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: selfishness, secrecy, and purpose. I wish I could get at what is the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: object of the latter. He seems to have some settled scheme of his own,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but what it is I do not yet know. His redeeming quality is a love of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: animals, though, indeed, he has such curious turns in it that I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sometimes imagine he is only abnormally cruel. His pets are of odd
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sorts. Just now his hobby is catching flies. He has at present such a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quantity that I have had myself to expostulate. To my astonishment, he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: did not break out into a fury, as I expected, but took the matter in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: simple seriousness. He thought for a moment, and then said: "May I have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: three days? I shall clear them away." Of course, I said that would do. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: must watch him.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _18 June._--He has turned his mind now to spiders, and has got several
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: very big fellows in a box. He keeps feeding them with his flies, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the number of the latter is becoming sensibly diminished, although he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: has used half his food in attracting more flies from outside to his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: room.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _1 July._--His spiders are now becoming as great a nuisance as his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flies, and to-day I told him that he must get rid of them. He looked
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: very sad at this, so I said that he must clear out some of them, at all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: events. He cheerfully acquiesced in this, and I gave him the same time
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as before for reduction. He disgusted me much while with him, for when a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: horrid blow-fly, bloated with some carrion food, buzzed into the room,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he caught it, held it exultantly for a few moments between his finger
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and thumb, and, before I knew what he was going to do, put it in his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mouth and ate it. I scolded him for it, but he argued quietly that it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was very good and very wholesome; that it was life, strong life, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gave life to him. This gave me an idea, or the rudiment of one. I must
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: watch how he gets rid of his spiders. He has evidently some deep problem
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in his mind, for he keeps a little note-book in which he is always
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: jotting down something. Whole pages of it are filled with masses of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: figures, generally single numbers added up in batches, and then the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: totals added in batches again, as though he were "focussing" some
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: account, as the auditors put it.

text: _8 July._--There is a method in his madness, and the rudimentary idea in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my mind is growing. It will be a whole idea soon, and then, oh,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: unconscious cerebration! you will have to give the wall to your
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: conscious brother. I kept away from my friend for a few days, so that I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: might notice if there were any change. Things remain as they were except
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: managed to get a sparrow, and has already partially tamed it. His means
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: tempting them with his food.
author: Stoker, Bram

text: _19 July._--We are progressing. My friend has now a whole colony of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sparrows, and his flies and spiders are almost obliterated. When I came
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in he ran to me and said he wanted to ask me a great favour--a very,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: very great favour; and as he spoke he fawned on me like a dog. I asked
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: him what it was, and he said, with a sort of rapture in his voice and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: bearing:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and teach, and feed--and feed--and feed!" I was not unprepared for this
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: request, for I had noticed how his pets went on increasing in size and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: vivacity, but I did not care that his pretty family of tame sparrows
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: should be wiped out in the same manner as the flies and the spiders; so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my head, and said that at present I feared it would not be possible, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that I would see about it. His face fell, and I could see a warning of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: more.

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

text: even him sleep, and took away his pocket-book to look at it. The thought
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gave many flies to one spider and many spiders to one bird, and then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: steps? It would almost be worth while to complete the experiment. It
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

text: racing for home, and rise and dip in the ground swell as they sweep into
author: Stoker, Bram

text: the harbour, bending to the scuppers. Here comes old Mr. Swales. He is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: making straight for me, and I can see, by the way he lifts his hat, that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he wants to talk....
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I have been quite touched by the change in the poor old man. When he sat
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: down beside me, he said in a very gentle way:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I want to say something to you, miss." I could see he was not at ease,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so I took his poor old wrinkled hand in mine and asked him to speak
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fully; so he said, leaving his hand in mine:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I'm afraid, my deary, that I must have shocked you by all the wicked
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: things I've been sayin' about the dead, and such like, for weeks past;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but I didn't mean them, and I want ye to remember that when I'm gone. We
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: aud folks that be daffled, and with one foot abaft the krok-hooal, don't
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: altogether like to think of it, and we don't want to feel scart of it;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: an' that's why I've took to makin' light of it, so that I'd cheer up my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: own heart a bit. But, Lord love ye, miss, I ain't afraid of dyin', not a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: bit; only I don't want to die if I can help it. My time must be nigh at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hand now, for I be aud, and a hundred years is too much for any man to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: expect; and I'm so nigh it that the Aud Man is already whettin' his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: scythe. Ye see, I can't get out o' the habit of caffin' about it all at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: once; the chafts will wag as they be used to. Some day soon the Angel of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Death will sound his trumpet for me. But don't ye dooal an' greet, my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: deary!"--for he saw that I was crying--"if he should come this very
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night I'd not refuse to answer his call. For life be, after all, only a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: waitin' for somethin' else than what we're doin'; and death be all that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we can rightly depend on. But I'm content, for it's comin' to me, my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: deary, and comin' quick. It may be comin' while we be lookin' and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wonderin'. Maybe it's in that wind out over the sea that's bringin' with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it loss and wreck, and sore distress, and sad hearts. Look! look!" he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cried suddenly. "There's something in that wind and in the hoast beyont
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that sounds, and looks, and tastes, and smells like death. It's in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: air; I feel it comin'. Lord, make me answer cheerful when my call
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: comes!" He held up his arms devoutly, and raised his hat. His mouth
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: moved as though he were praying. After a few minutes' silence, he got
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: up, shook hands with me, and blessed me, and said good-bye, and hobbled
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: off. It all touched me, and upset me very much.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

text: arm. He stopped to talk with me, as he always does, but all the time
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

text: _Whitby_.

text: One of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: experienced here, with results both strange and unique. The weather had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: been somewhat sultry, but not to any degree uncommon in the month of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the neighbourhood of Whitby. The steamers _Emma_ and _Scarborough_ made
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: trips up and down the coast, and there was an unusual amount of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "tripping" both to and from Whitby. The day was unusually fine till the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: afternoon, when some of the gossips who frequent the East Cliff
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: churchyard, and from that commanding eminence watch the wide sweep of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: language is ranked "No. 2: light breeze." The coastguard on duty at once
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

text: noble as that of the young Casabianca--and placed in the mortuary to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: await inquest.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Already the sudden storm is passing, and its fierceness is abating;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: crowds are scattering homeward, and the sky is beginning to redden over
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the Yorkshire wolds. I shall send, in time for your next issue, further
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: details of the derelict ship which found her way so miraculously into
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: harbour in the storm.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Whitby_
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _9 August._--The sequel to the strange arrival of the derelict in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: storm last night is almost more startling than the thing itself. It
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: turns out that the schooner is a Russian from Varna, and is called the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Demeter_. She is almost entirely in ballast of silver sand, with only a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: small amount of cargo--a number of great wooden boxes filled with mould.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: This cargo was consigned to a Whitby solicitor, Mr. S. F. Billington, of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: 7, The Crescent, who this morning went aboard and formally took
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: possession of the goods consigned to him. The Russian consul, too,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: acting for the charter-party, took formal possession of the ship, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: paid all harbour dues, etc. Nothing is talked about here to-day except
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the strange coincidence; the officials of the Board of Trade have been
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: most exacting in seeing that every compliance has been made with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: existing regulations. As the matter is to be a "nine days' wonder," they
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: are evidently determined that there shall be no cause of after
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: complaint. A good deal of interest was abroad concerning the dog which
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: landed when the ship struck, and more than a few of the members of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: S. P. C. A., which is very strong in Whitby, have tried to befriend the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: animal. To the general disappointment, however, it was not to be found;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it seems to have disappeared entirely from the town. It may be that it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was frightened and made its way on to the moors, where it is still
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hiding in terror. There are some who look with dread on such a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: possibility, lest later on it should in itself become a danger, for it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is evidently a fierce brute. Early this morning a large dog, a half-bred
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mastiff belonging to a coal merchant close to Tate Hill Pier, was found
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dead in the roadway opposite to its master's yard. It had been fighting,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and manifestly had had a savage opponent, for its throat was torn away,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and its belly was slit open as if with a savage claw.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Later._--By the kindness of the Board of Trade inspector, I have been
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: permitted to look over the log-book of the _Demeter_, which was in order
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: up to within three days, but contained nothing of special interest
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: except as to facts of missing men. The greatest interest, however, is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with regard to the paper found in the bottle, which was to-day produced
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: at the inquest; and a more strange narrative than the two between them
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: unfold it has not been my lot to come across. As there is no motive for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: concealment, I am permitted to use them, and accordingly send you a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rescript, simply omitting technical details of seamanship and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: supercargo. It almost seems as though the captain had been seized with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: some kind of mania before he had got well into blue water, and that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this had developed persistently throughout the voyage. Of course my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: statement must be taken _cum grano_, since I am writing from the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dictation of a clerk of the Russian consul, who kindly translated for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me, time being short.

text: _Written 18 July, things so strange happening, that I shall keep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: accurate note henceforth till we land._
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: On 6 July we finished taking in cargo, silver sand and boxes of earth.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: At noon set sail. East wind, fresh. Crew, five hands ... two mates,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cook, and myself (captain).
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: On 11 July at dawn entered Bosphorus. Boarded by Turkish Customs
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: officers. Backsheesh. All correct. Under way at 4 p. m.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: On 12 July through Dardanelles. More Customs officers and flagboat of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: guarding squadron. Backsheesh again. Work of officers thorough, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quick. Want us off soon. At dark passed into Archipelago.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: On 13 July passed Cape Matapan. Crew dissatisfied about something.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Seemed scared, but would not speak out.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: On 14 July was somewhat anxious about crew. Men all steady fellows, who
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sailed with me before. Mate could not make out what was wrong; they only
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: told him there was _something_, and crossed themselves. Mate lost temper
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with one of them that day and struck him. Expected fierce quarrel, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all was quiet.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: On 16 July mate reported in the morning that one of crew, Petrofsky, was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: missing. Could not account for it. Took larboard watch eight bells last
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night; was relieved by Abramoff, but did not go to bunk. Men more
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: downcast than ever. All said they expected something of the kind, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: would not say more than there was _something_ aboard. Mate getting very
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: impatient with them; feared some trouble ahead.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: On 17 July, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin, and in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: an awestruck way confided to me that he thought there was a strange man
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: aboard the ship. He said that in his watch he had been sheltering
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: behind the deck-house, as there was a rain-storm, when he saw a tall,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thin man, who was not like any of the crew, come up the companion-way,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and go along the deck forward, and disappear. He followed cautiously,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but when he got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: He was in a panic of superstitious fear, and I am afraid the panic may
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: spread. To allay it, I shall to-day search entire ship carefully from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stem to stern.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Later in the day I got together the whole crew, and told them, as they
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: evidently thought there was some one in the ship, we would search from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stem to stern. First mate angry; said it was folly, and to yield to such
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: foolish ideas would demoralise the men; said he would engage to keep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them out of trouble with a handspike. I let him take the helm, while the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rest began thorough search, all keeping abreast, with lanterns: we left
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: no corner unsearched. As there were only the big wooden boxes, there
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: were no odd corners where a man could hide. Men much relieved when
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: search over, and went back to work cheerfully. First mate scowled, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: said nothing.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _22 July_.--Rough weather last three days, and all hands busy with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sails--no time to be frightened. Men seem to have forgotten their dread.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Mate cheerful again, and all on good terms. Praised men for work in bad
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: weather. Passed Gibralter and out through Straits. All well.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _24 July_.--There seems some doom over this ship. Already a hand short,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and entering on the Bay of Biscay with wild weather ahead, and yet last
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night another man lost--disappeared. Like the first, he came off his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: watch and was not seen again. Men all in a panic of fear; sent a round
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: robin, asking to have double watch, as they fear to be alone. Mate
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: angry. Fear there will be some trouble, as either he or the men will do
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: some violence.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _28 July_.--Four days in hell, knocking about in a sort of maelstrom,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and the wind a tempest. No sleep for any one. Men all worn out. Hardly
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: know how to set a watch, since no one fit to go on. Second mate
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: volunteered to steer and watch, and let men snatch a few hours' sleep.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Wind abating; seas still terrific, but feel them less, as ship is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: steadier.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _29 July_.--Another tragedy. Had single watch to-night, as crew too
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: tired to double. When morning watch came on deck could find no one
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: except steersman. Raised outcry, and all came on deck. Thorough search,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but no one found. Are now without second mate, and crew in a panic. Mate
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and I agreed to go armed henceforth and wait for any sign of cause.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _30 July_.--Last night. Rejoiced we are nearing England. Weather fine,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all sails set. Retired worn out; slept soundly; awaked by mate telling
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me that both man of watch and steersman missing. Only self and mate and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: two hands left to work ship.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _1 August_.--Two days of fog, and not a sail sighted. Had hoped when in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the English Channel to be able to signal for help or get in somewhere.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Not having power to work sails, have to run before wind. Dare not lower,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as could not raise them again. We seem to be drifting to some terrible
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: doom. Mate now more demoralised than either of men. His stronger nature
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seems to have worked inwardly against himself. Men are beyond fear,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: working stolidly and patiently, with minds made up to worst. They are
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Russian, he Roumanian.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _2 August, midnight_.--Woke up from few minutes' sleep by hearing a cry,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seemingly outside my port. Could see nothing in fog. Rushed on deck, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ran against mate. Tells me heard cry and ran, but no sign of man on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: watch. One more gone. Lord, help us! Mate says we must be past Straits
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of Dover, as in a moment of fog lifting he saw North Foreland, just as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he heard the man cry out. If so we are now off in the North Sea, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: only God can guide us in the fog, which seems to move with us; and God
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seems to have deserted us.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _3 August_.--At midnight I went to relieve the man at the wheel, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: when I got to it found no one there. The wind was steady, and as we ran
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: before it there was no yawing. I dared not leave it, so shouted for the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mate. After a few seconds he rushed up on deck in his flannels. He
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: looked wild-eyed and haggard, and I greatly fear his reason has given
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: way. He came close to me and whispered hoarsely, with his mouth to my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ear, as though fearing the very air might hear: "_It_ is here; I know
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it, now. On the watch last night I saw It, like a man, tall and thin,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and ghastly pale. It was in the bows, and looking out. I crept behind
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: It, and gave It my knife; but the knife went through It, empty as the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: air." And as he spoke he took his knife and drove it savagely into
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: space. Then he went on: "But It is here, and I'll find It. It is in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hold, perhaps in one of those boxes. I'll unscrew them one by one and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: see. You work the helm." And, with a warning look and his finger on his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lip, he went below. There was springing up a choppy wind, and I could
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not leave the helm. I saw him come out on deck again with a tool-chest
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and a lantern, and go down the forward hatchway. He is mad, stark,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: raving mad, and it's no use my trying to stop him. He can't hurt those
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: big boxes: they are invoiced as "clay," and to pull them about is as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: harmless a thing as he can do. So here I stay, and mind the helm, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: write these notes. I can only trust in God and wait till the fog clears.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Then, if I can't steer to any harbour with the wind that is, I shall cut
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: down sails and lie by, and signal for help....
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: It is nearly all over now. Just as I was beginning to hope that the mate
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: would come out calmer--for I heard him knocking away at something in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hold, and work is good for him--there came up the hatchway a sudden,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: startled scream, which made my blood run cold, and up on the deck he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: came as if shot from a gun--a raging madman, with his eyes rolling and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his face convulsed with fear. "Save me! save me!" he cried, and then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: looked round on the blanket of fog. His horror turned to despair, and in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a steady voice he said: "You had better come too, captain, before it is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: too late. _He_ is there. I know the secret now. The sea will save me
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: from Him, and it is all that is left!" Before I could say a word, or
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: move forward to seize him, he sprang on the bulwark and deliberately
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: threw himself into the sea. I suppose I know the secret too, now. It was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this madman who had got rid of the men one by one, and now he has
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: followed them himself. God help me! How am I to account for all these
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: horrors when I get to port? _When_ I get to port! Will that ever be?
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _4 August._--Still fog, which the sunrise cannot pierce. I know there is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sunrise because I am a sailor, why else I know not. I dared not go
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: below, I dared not leave the helm; so here all night I stayed, and in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the dimness of the night I saw It--Him! God forgive me, but the mate was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: right to jump overboard. It was better to die like a man; to die like a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sailor in blue water no man can object. But I am captain, and I must not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: leave my ship. But I shall baffle this fiend or monster, for I shall tie
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my hands to the wheel when my strength begins to fail, and along with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them I shall tie that which He--It!--dare not touch; and then, come good
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wind or foul, I shall save my soul, and my honour as a captain. I am
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: growing weaker, and the night is coming on. If He can look me in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: face again, I may not have time to act.... If we are wrecked, mayhap
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this bottle may be found, and those who find it may understand; if not,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ... well, then all men shall know that I have been true to my trust. God
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and the Blessed Virgin and the saints help a poor ignorant soul trying
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to do his duty....
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Of course the verdict was an open one. There is no evidence to adduce;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and whether or not the man himself committed the murders there is now
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: none to say. The folk here hold almost universally that the captain is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: simply a hero, and he is to be given a public funeral. Already it is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: arranged that his body is to be taken with a train of boats up the Esk
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for a piece and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and up the abbey
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: steps; for he is to be buried in the churchyard on the cliff. The owners
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of more than a hundred boats have already given in their names as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wishing to follow him to the grave.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: No trace has ever been found of the great dog; at which there is much
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mourning, for, with public opinion in its present state, he would, I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: believe, be adopted by the town. To-morrow will see the funeral; and so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: will end this one more "mystery of the sea."

author: Stoker, Bram

text: _8 August._--Lucy was very restless all night, and I, too, could not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sleep. The storm was fearful, and as it boomed loudly among the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: chimney-pots, it made me shudder. When a sharp puff came it seemed to be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: like a distant gun. Strangely enough, Lucy did not wake; but she got up
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: twice and dressed herself. Fortunately, each time I awoke in time and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: managed to undress her without waking her, and got her back to bed. It
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is a very strange thing, this sleep-walking, for as soon as her will is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thwarted in any physical way, her intention, if there be any,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: disappears, and she yields herself almost exactly to the routine of her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: life.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Early in the morning we both got up and went down to the harbour to see
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: if anything had happened in the night. There were very few people about,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and though the sun was bright, and the air clear and fresh, the big,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: grim-looking waves, that seemed dark themselves because the foam that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: topped them was like snow, forced themselves in through the narrow mouth
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of the harbour--like a bullying man going through a crowd. Somehow I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: felt glad that Jonathan was not on the sea last night, but on land. But,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: oh, is he on land or sea? Where is he, and how? I am getting fearfully
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: anxious about him. If I only knew what to do, and could do anything!
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
