author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: touching. Every boat in the harbour seemed to be there, and the coffin
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was carried by captains all the way from Tate Hill Pier up to the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: churchyard. Lucy came with me, and we went early to our old seat, whilst
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the cortège of boats went up the river to the Viaduct and came down
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: again. We had a lovely view, and saw the procession nearly all the way.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The poor fellow was laid to rest quite near our seat so that we stood on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it when the time came and saw everything. Poor Lucy seemed much upset.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: She was restless and uneasy all the time, and I cannot but think that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: her dreaming at night is telling on her. She is quite odd in one thing:
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: she will not admit to me that there is any cause for restlessness; or if
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: there be, she does not understand it herself. There is an additional
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cause in that poor old Mr. Swales was found dead this morning on our
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seat, his neck being broken. He had evidently, as the doctor said,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fallen back in the seat in some sort of fright, for there was a look of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fear and horror on his face that the men said made them shudder. Poor
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dear old man! Perhaps he had seen Death with his dying eyes! Lucy is so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sweet and sensitive that she feels influences more acutely than other
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: people do. Just now she was quite upset by a little thing which I did
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not much heed, though I am myself very fond of animals. One of the men
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: who came up here often to look for the boats was followed by his dog.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The dog is always with him. They are both quiet persons, and I never saw
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the man angry, nor heard the dog bark. During the service the dog would
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not come to its master, who was on the seat with us, but kept a few
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: yards off, barking and howling. Its master spoke to it gently, and then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: harshly, and then angrily; but it would neither come nor cease to make a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: noise. It was in a sort of fury, with its eyes savage, and all its hairs
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: bristling out like a cat's tail when puss is on the war-path. Finally
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the man, too, got angry, and jumped down and kicked the dog, and then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: took it by the scruff of the neck and half dragged and half threw it on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the tombstone on which the seat is fixed. The moment it touched the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stone the poor thing became quiet and fell all into a tremble. It did
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not try to get away, but crouched down, quivering and cowering, and was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in such a pitiable state of terror that I tried, though without effect,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to comfort it. Lucy was full of pity, too, but she did not attempt to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: touch the dog, but looked at it in an agonised sort of way. I greatly
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fear that she is of too super-sensitive a nature to go through the world
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: without trouble. She will be dreaming of this to-night, I am sure. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: whole agglomeration of things--the ship steered into port by a dead
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: man; his attitude, tied to the wheel with a crucifix and beads; the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: touching funeral; the dog, now furious and now in terror--will all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: afford material for her dreams.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I think it will be best for her to go to bed tired out physically, so I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shall take her for a long walk by the cliffs to Robin Hood's Bay and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: back. She ought not to have much inclination for sleep-walking then.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: CHAPTER VIII
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: MINA MURRAY'S JOURNAL
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Same day, 11 o'clock p. m._--Oh, but I am tired! If it were not that I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had made my diary a duty I should not open it to-night. We had a lovely
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: walk. Lucy, after a while, was in gay spirits, owing, I think, to some
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dear cows who came nosing towards us in a field close to the lighthouse,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and frightened the wits out of us. I believe we forgot everything
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: except, of course, personal fear, and it seemed to wipe the slate clean
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and give us a fresh start. We had a capital "severe tea" at Robin Hood's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Bay in a sweet little old-fashioned inn, with a bow-window right over
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the seaweed-covered rocks of the strand. I believe we should have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shocked the "New Woman" with our appetites. Men are more tolerant, bless
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them! Then we walked home with some, or rather many, stoppages to rest,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and with our hearts full of a constant dread of wild bulls. Lucy was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: really tired, and we intended to creep off to bed as soon as we could.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The young curate came in, however, and Mrs. Westenra asked him to stay
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for supper. Lucy and I had both a fight for it with the dusty miller; I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: know it was a hard fight on my part, and I am quite heroic. I think that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: some day the bishops must get together and see about breeding up a new
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: class of curates, who don't take supper, no matter how they may be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pressed to, and who will know when girls are tired. Lucy is asleep and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: breathing softly. She has more colour in her cheeks than usual, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: looks, oh, so sweet. If Mr. Holmwood fell in love with her seeing her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: only in the drawing-room, I wonder what he would say if he saw her now.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Some of the "New Women" writers will some day start an idea that men and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: women should be allowed to see each other asleep before proposing or
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: accepting. But I suppose the New Woman won't condescend in future to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: accept; she will do the proposing herself. And a nice job she will make
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of it, too! There's some consolation in that. I am so happy to-night,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: because dear Lucy seems better. I really believe she has turned the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: corner, and that we are over her troubles with dreaming. I should be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quite happy if I only knew if Jonathan.... God bless and keep him.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _11 August, 3 a. m._--Diary again. No sleep now, so I may as well write.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I am too agitated to sleep. We have had such an adventure, such an
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: agonising experience. I fell asleep as soon as I had closed my diary....
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Suddenly I became broad awake, and sat up, with a horrible sense of fear
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: upon me, and of some feeling of emptiness around me. The room was dark,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so I could not see Lucy's bed; I stole across and felt for her. The bed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was empty. I lit a match and found that she was not in the room. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: door was shut, but not locked, as I had left it. I feared to wake her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mother, who has been more than usually ill lately, so threw on some
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: clothes and got ready to look for her. As I was leaving the room it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: struck me that the clothes she wore might give me some clue to her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dreaming intention. Dressing-gown would mean house; dress, outside.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Dressing-gown and dress were both in their places. "Thank God," I said
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to myself, "she cannot be far, as she is only in her nightdress." I ran
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: downstairs and looked in the sitting-room. Not there! Then I looked in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all the other open rooms of the house, with an ever-growing fear
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: chilling my heart. Finally I came to the hall door and found it open. It
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was not wide open, but the catch of the lock had not caught. The people
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of the house are careful to lock the door every night, so I feared that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Lucy must have gone out as she was. There was no time to think of what
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: might happen; a vague, overmastering fear obscured all details. I took a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: big, heavy shawl and ran out. The clock was striking one as I was in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Crescent, and there was not a soul in sight. I ran along the North
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Terrace, but could see no sign of the white figure which I expected. At
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the edge of the West Cliff above the pier I looked across the harbour to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the East Cliff, in the hope or fear--I don't know which--of seeing Lucy
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in our favourite seat. There was a bright full moon, with heavy black,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: driving clouds, which threw the whole scene into a fleeting diorama of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: light and shade as they sailed across. For a moment or two I could see
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: nothing, as the shadow of a cloud obscured St. Mary's Church and all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: around it. Then as the cloud passed I could see the ruins of the abbey
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: coming into view; and as the edge of a narrow band of light as sharp as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a sword-cut moved along, the church and the churchyard became gradually
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: visible. Whatever my expectation was, it was not disappointed, for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: there, on our favourite seat, the silver light of the moon struck a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: half-reclining figure, snowy white. The coming of the cloud was too
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quick for me to see much, for shadow shut down on light almost
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: immediately; but it seemed to me as though something dark stood behind
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the seat where the white figure shone, and bent over it. What it was,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: whether man or beast, I could not tell; I did not wait to catch another
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: glance, but flew down the steep steps to the pier and along by the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fish-market to the bridge, which was the only way to reach the East
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Cliff. The town seemed as dead, for not a soul did I see; I rejoiced
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that it was so, for I wanted no witness of poor Lucy's condition. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: time and distance seemed endless, and my knees trembled and my breath
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: came laboured as I toiled up the endless steps to the abbey. I must have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gone fast, and yet it seemed to me as if my feet were weighted with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lead, and as though every joint in my body were rusty. When I got almost
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to the top I could see the seat and the white figure, for I was now
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: close enough to distinguish it even through the spells of shadow. There
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was undoubtedly something, long and black, bending over the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: half-reclining white figure. I called in fright, "Lucy! Lucy!" and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: something raised a head, and from where I was I could see a white face
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and red, gleaming eyes. Lucy did not answer, and I ran on to the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: entrance of the churchyard. As I entered, the church was between me and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the seat, and for a minute or so I lost sight of her. When I came in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: view again the cloud had passed, and the moonlight struck so brilliantly
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that I could see Lucy half reclining with her head lying over the back
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of the seat. She was quite alone, and there was not a sign of any living
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thing about.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: were parted, and she was breathing--not softly as usual with her, but in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: breath. As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: collar of her nightdress close around her throat. Whilst she did so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. When I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: very gently to wake her. At first she did not respond; but gradually she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: became more and more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: till finally she opened her eyes and awoke. She did not seem surprised
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace. She
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince. She
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Fortune favoured us, and we got home without meeting a soul. Once we saw
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a man, who seemed not quite sober, passing along a street in front of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: us; but we hid in a door till he had disappeared up an opening such as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: there are here, steep little closes, or "wynds," as they call them in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Scotland. My heart beat so loud all the time that sometimes I thought I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: should faint. I was filled with anxiety about Lucy, not only for her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: health, lest she should suffer from the exposure, but for her reputation
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in case the story should get wind. When we got in, and had washed our
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: feet, and had said a prayer of thankfulness together, I tucked her into
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: bed. Before falling asleep she asked--even implored--me not to say a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: word to any one, even her mother, about her sleep-walking adventure. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hesitated at first to promise; but on thinking of the state of her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mother's health, and how the knowledge of such a thing would fret her,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and thinking, too, of how such a story might become distorted--nay,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: infallibly would--in case it should leak out, I thought it wiser to do
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so. I hope I did right. I have locked the door, and the key is tied to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my wrist, so perhaps I shall not be again disturbed. Lucy is sleeping
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: soundly; the reflex of the dawn is high and far over the sea....
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Same day, noon._--All goes well. Lucy slept till I woke her and seemed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not to have even changed her side. The adventure of the night does not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seem to have harmed her; on the contrary, it has benefited her, for she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: looks better this morning than she has done for weeks. I was sorry to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: notice that my clumsiness with the safety-pin hurt her. Indeed, it might
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have been serious, for the skin of her throat was pierced. I must have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pinched up a piece of loose skin and have transfixed it, for there are
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: two little red points like pin-pricks, and on the band of her nightdress
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was a drop of blood. When I apologised and was concerned about it, she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: laughed and petted me, and said she did not even feel it. Fortunately it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cannot leave a scar, as it is so tiny.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Same day, night._--We passed a happy day. The air was clear, and the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sun bright, and there was a cool breeze. We took our lunch to Mulgrave
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Woods, Mrs. Westenra driving by the road and Lucy and I walking by the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cliff-path and joining her at the gate. I felt a little sad myself, for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I could not but feel how _absolutely_ happy it would have been had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Jonathan been with me. But there! I must only be patient. In the evening
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we strolled in the Casino Terrace, and heard some good music by Spohr
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and Mackenzie, and went to bed early. Lucy seems more restful than she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: has been for some time, and fell asleep at once. I shall lock the door
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and secure the key the same as before, though I do not expect any
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: trouble to-night.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _12 August._--My expectations were wrong, for twice during the night I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was wakened by Lucy trying to get out. She seemed, even in her sleep, to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be a little impatient at finding the door shut, and went back to bed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: under a sort of protest. I woke with the dawn, and heard the birds
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: chirping outside of the window. Lucy woke, too, and, I was glad to see,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was even better than on the previous morning. All her old gaiety of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: manner seemed to have come back, and she came and snuggled in beside me
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and told me all about Arthur. I told her how anxious I was about
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Jonathan, and then she tried to comfort me. Well, she succeeded
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: somewhat, for, though sympathy can't alter facts, it can help to make
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them more bearable.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _13 August._--Another quiet day, and to bed with the key on my wrist as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: before. Again I awoke in the night, and found Lucy sitting up in bed,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: still asleep, pointing to the window. I got up quietly, and pulling
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: aside the blind, looked out. It was brilliant moonlight, and the soft
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: effect of the light over the sea and sky--merged together in one great,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: silent mystery--was beautiful beyond words. Between me and the moonlight
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flitted a great bat, coming and going in great whirling circles. Once or
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: twice it came quite close, but was, I suppose, frightened at seeing me,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _14 August._--On the East Cliff, reading and writing all day. Lucy seems
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to have become as much in love with the spot as I am, and it is hard to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: get her away from it when it is time to come home for lunch or tea or
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dinner. This afternoon she made a funny remark. We were coming home for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dinner, and had come to the top of the steps up from the West Pier and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stopped to look at the view, as we generally do. The setting sun, low
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thrown over on the East Cliff and the old abbey, and seemed to bathe
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "His red eyes again! They are just the same." It was such an odd
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: at her, and saw that she was in a half-dreamy state, with an odd look on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: followed her eyes. She appeared to be looking over at our own seat,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: whereon was a dark figure seated alone. I was a little startled myself,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for it seemed for an instant as if the stranger had great eyes like
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seat, and as the sun dipped there was just sufficient change in the
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

text: record of what took place to-night. I feel I am dying of weakness, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have barely strength to write, but it must be done if I die in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: doing.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I went to bed as usual, taking care that the flowers were placed as Dr.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing directed, and soon fell asleep.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I was waked by the flapping at the window, which had begun after that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sleep-walking on the cliff at Whitby when Mina saved me, and which now I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: know so well. I was not afraid, but I did wish that Dr. Seward was in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the next room--as Dr. Van Helsing said he would be--so that I might have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: called him. I tried to go to sleep, but could not. Then there came to me
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the old fear of sleep, and I determined to keep awake. Perversely sleep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: would try to come then when I did not want it; so, as I feared to be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: alone, I opened my door and called out: "Is there anybody there?" There
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was no answer. I was afraid to wake mother, and so closed my door again.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Then outside in the shrubbery I heard a sort of howl like a dog's, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: more fierce and deeper. I went to the window and looked out, but could
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: see nothing, except a big bat, which had evidently been buffeting its
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wings against the window. So I went back to bed again, but determined
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not to go to sleep. Presently the door opened, and mother looked in;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seeing by my moving that I was not asleep, came in, and sat by me. She
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: said to me even more sweetly and softly than her wont:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I was uneasy about you, darling, and came in to see that you were all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: right."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I feared she might catch cold sitting there, and asked her to come in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and sleep with me, so she came into bed, and lay down beside me; she did
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not take off her dressing gown, for she said she would only stay a while
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and then go back to her own bed. As she lay there in my arms, and I in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hers, the flapping and buffeting came to the window again. She was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: startled and a little frightened, and cried out: "What is that?" I tried
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to pacify her, and at last succeeded, and she lay quiet; but I could
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hear her poor dear heart still beating terribly. After a while there was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the low howl again out in the shrubbery, and shortly after there was a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: crash at the window, and a lot of broken glass was hurled on the floor.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The window blind blew back with the wind that rushed in, and in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: aperture of the broken panes there was the head of a great, gaunt grey
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wolf. Mother cried out in a fright, and struggled up into a sitting
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: posture, and clutched wildly at anything that would help her. Amongst
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: other things, she clutched the wreath of flowers that Dr. Van Helsing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: insisted on my wearing round my neck, and tore it away from me. For a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: second or two she sat up, pointing at the wolf, and there was a strange
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and horrible gurgling in her throat; then she fell over--as if struck
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with lightning, and her head hit my forehead and made me dizzy for a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: moment or two. The room and all round seemed to spin round. I kept my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: eyes fixed on the window, but the wolf drew his head back, and a whole
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: myriad of little specks seemed to come blowing in through the broken
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: window, and wheeling and circling round like the pillar of dust that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: travellers describe when there is a simoon in the desert. I tried to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stir, but there was some spell upon me, and dear mother's poor body,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: which seemed to grow cold already--for her dear heart had ceased to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: beat--weighed me down; and I remembered no more for a while.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body of my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mother's breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had told me, but I didn't like to remove them, and, besides, I would
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to the dining-room to look for them.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: My heart sank when I saw what had happened. They all four lay helpless
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: on the floor, breathing heavily. The decanter of sherry was on the table
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: half full, but there was a queer, acrid smell about. I was suspicious,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and examined the decanter. It smelt of laudanum, and looking on the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sideboard, I found that the bottle which mother's doctor uses for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: her--oh! did use--was empty. What am I to do? what am I to do? I am back
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in the room with mother. I cannot leave her, and I am alone, save for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the sleeping servants, whom some one has drugged. Alone with the dead! I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dare not go out, for I can hear the low howl of the wolf through the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: broken window.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The air seems full of specks, floating and circling in the draught from
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the window, and the lights burn blue and dim. What am I to do? God
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shield me from harm this night! I shall hide this paper in my breast,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: where they shall find it when they come to lay me out. My dear mother
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gone! It is time that I go too. Good-bye, dear Arthur, if I should not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: survive this night. God keep you, dear, and God help me!
author: Stoker, Bram

text: CHAPTER XII
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: DR. SEWARD'S DIARY
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _18 September._--I drove at once to Hillingham and arrived early.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Keeping my cab at the gate, I went up the avenue alone. I knocked gently
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and rang as quietly as possible, for I feared to disturb Lucy or her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mother, and hoped to only bring a servant to the door. After a while,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: finding no response, I knocked and rang again; still no answer. I cursed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the laziness of the servants that they should lie abed at such an
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hour--for it was now ten o'clock--and so rang and knocked again, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: more impatiently, but still without response. Hitherto I had blamed only
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the servants, but now a terrible fear began to assail me. Was this
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: desolation but another link in the chain of doom which seemed drawing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: tight around us? Was it indeed a house of death to which I had come, too
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: late? I knew that minutes, even seconds of delay, might mean hours of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: danger to Lucy, if she had had again one of those frightful relapses;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and I went round the house to try if I could find by chance an entry
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: anywhere.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I could find no means of ingress. Every window and door was fastened and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: locked, and I returned baffled to the porch. As I did so, I heard the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rapid pit-pat of a swiftly driven horse's feet. They stopped at the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gate, and a few seconds later I met Van Helsing running up the avenue.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: When he saw me, he gasped out:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Then it was you, and just arrived. How is she? Are we too late? Did you
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not get my telegram?"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I answered as quickly and coherently as I could that I had only got his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: telegram early in the morning, and had not lost a minute in coming here,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and that I could not make any one in the house hear me. He paused and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: raised his hat as he said solemnly:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Then I fear we are too late. God's will be done!" With his usual
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: recuperative energy, he went on: "Come. If there be no way open to get
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in, we must make one. Time is all in all to us now."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: We went round to the back of the house, where there was a kitchen
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: window. The Professor took a small surgical saw from his case, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: handing it to me, pointed to the iron bars which guarded the window. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: attacked them at once and had very soon cut through three of them. Then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with a long, thin knife we pushed back the fastening of the sashes and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: opened the window. I helped the Professor in, and followed him. There
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was no one in the kitchen or in the servants' rooms, which were close at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hand. We tried all the rooms as we went along, and in the dining-room,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dimly lit by rays of light through the shutters, found four
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: servant-women lying on the floor. There was no need to think them dead,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for their stertorous breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: room left no doubt as to their condition. Van Helsing and I looked at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: each other, and as we moved away he said: "We can attend to them later."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Then we ascended to Lucy's room. For an instant or two we paused at the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: door to listen, but there was no sound that we could hear. With white
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: faces and trembling hands, we opened the door gently, and entered the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: room.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: How shall I describe what we saw? On the bed lay two women, Lucy and her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mother. The latter lay farthest in, and she was covered with a white
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sheet, the edge of which had been blown back by the draught through the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: broken window, showing the drawn, white face, with a look of terror
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fixed upon it. By her side lay Lucy, with face white and still more
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: drawn. The flowers which had been round her neck we found upon her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mother's bosom, and her throat was bare, showing the two little wounds
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: which we had noticed before, but looking horribly white and mangled.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Without a word the Professor bent over the bed, his head almost touching
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: poor Lucy's breast; then he gave a quick turn of his head, as of one who
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: listens, and leaping to his feet, he cried out to me:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "It is not yet too late! Quick! quick! Bring the brandy!"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I flew downstairs and returned with it, taking care to smell and taste
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it, lest it, too, were drugged like the decanter of sherry which I found
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: on the table. The maids were still breathing, but more restlessly, and I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fancied that the narcotic was wearing off. I did not stay to make sure,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: but returned to Van Helsing. He rubbed the brandy, as on another
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: occasion, on her lips and gums and on her wrists and the palms of her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hands. He said to me:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I can do this, all that can be at the present. You go wake those maids.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Flick them in the face with a wet towel, and flick them hard. Make them
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: get heat and fire and a warm bath. This poor soul is nearly as cold as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that beside her. She will need be heated before we can do anything
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: more."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I went at once, and found little difficulty in waking three of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: women. The fourth was only a young girl, and the drug had evidently
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: affected her more strongly, so I lifted her on the sofa and let her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sleep. The others were dazed at first, but as remembrance came back to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them they cried and sobbed in a hysterical manner. I was stern with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them, however, and would not let them talk. I told them that one life
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was bad enough to lose, and that if they delayed they would sacrifice
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Miss Lucy. So, sobbing and crying, they went about their way, half clad
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as they were, and prepared fire and water. Fortunately, the kitchen and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: boiler fires were still alive, and there was no lack of hot water. We
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: got a bath and carried Lucy out as she was and placed her in it. Whilst
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we were busy chafing her limbs there was a knock at the hall door. One
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of the maids ran off, hurried on some more clothes, and opened it. Then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: she returned and whispered to us that there was a gentleman who had come
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with a message from Mr. Holmwood. I bade her simply tell him that he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: must wait, for we could see no one now. She went away with the message,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and, engrossed with our work, I clean forgot all about him.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I never saw in all my experience the Professor work in such deadly
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: earnest. I knew--as he knew--that it was a stand-up fight with death,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and in a pause told him so. He answered me in a way that I did not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: understand, but with the sternest look that his face could wear:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "If that were all, I would stop here where we are now, and let her fade
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: away into peace, for I see no light in life over her horizon." He went
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: on with his work with, if possible, renewed and more frenzied vigour.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Presently we both began to be conscious that the heat was beginning to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be of some effect. Lucy's heart beat a trifle more audibly to the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stethoscope, and her lungs had a perceptible movement. Van Helsing's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: face almost beamed, and as we lifted her from the bath and rolled her in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a hot sheet to dry her he said to me:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "The first gain is ours! Check to the King!"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: We took Lucy into another room, which had by now been prepared, and laid
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: her in bed and forced a few drops of brandy down her throat. I noticed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that Van Helsing tied a soft silk handkerchief round her throat. She was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: still unconscious, and was quite as bad as, if not worse than, we had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ever seen her.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing called in one of the women, and told her to stay with her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and not to take her eyes off her till we returned, and then beckoned me
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: out of the room.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "We must consult as to what is to be done," he said as we descended the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stairs. In the hall he opened the dining-room door, and we passed in, he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: closing the door carefully behind him. The shutters had been opened, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the blinds were already down, with that obedience to the etiquette of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: death which the British woman of the lower classes always rigidly
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: observes. The room was, therefore, dimly dark. It was, however, light
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: enough for our purposes. Van Helsing's sternness was somewhat relieved
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: by a look of perplexity. He was evidently torturing his mind about
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: something, so I waited for an instant, and he spoke:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "What are we to do now? Where are we to turn for help? We must have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: another transfusion of blood, and that soon, or that poor girl's life
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: won't be worth an hour's purchase. You are exhausted already; I am
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: exhausted too. I fear to trust those women, even if they would have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: courage to submit. What are we to do for some one who will open his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: veins for her?"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "What's the matter with me, anyhow?"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The voice came from the sofa across the room, and its tones brought
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: relief and joy to my heart, for they were those of Quincey Morris. Van
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Helsing started angrily at the first sound, but his face softened and a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: glad look came into his eyes as I cried out: "Quincey Morris!" and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rushed towards him with outstretched hands.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "What brought you here?" I cried as our hands met.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I guess Art is the cause."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: He handed me a telegram:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Have not heard from Seward for three days, and am terribly anxious.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Cannot leave. Father still in same condition. Send me word how Lucy is.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Do not delay.--HOLMWOOD."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I think I came just in the nick of time. You know you have only to tell
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me what to do."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing strode forward, and took his hand, looking him straight in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the eyes as he said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "A brave man's blood is the best thing on this earth when a woman is in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: trouble. You're a man and no mistake. Well, the devil may work against

text: "My dearest Lucy,--
author: Stoker, Bram

text: "Such a sad blow has befallen us. Mr. Hawkins has died very suddenly.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

text: _20 September._--Only resolution and habit can let me make an entry
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to-night. I am too miserable, too low-spirited, too sick of the world
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and all in it, including life itself, that I would not care if I heard
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this moment the flapping of the wings of the angel of death. And he has
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: been flapping those grim wings to some purpose of late--Lucy's mother
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and Arthur's father, and now.... Let me get on with my work.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I duly relieved Van Helsing in his watch over Lucy. We wanted Arthur to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: go to rest also, but he refused at first. It was only when I told him
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that we should want him to help us during the day, and that we must not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all break down for want of rest, lest Lucy should suffer, that he agreed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to go. Van Helsing was very kind to him. "Come, my child," he said;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "come with me. You are sick and weak, and have had much sorrow and much
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mental pain, as well as that tax on your strength that we know of. You
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: must not be alone; for to be alone is to be full of fears and alarms.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Come to the drawing-room, where there is a big fire, and there are two
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sofas. You shall lie on one, and I on the other, and our sympathy will
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be comfort to each other, even though we do not speak, and even if we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sleep." Arthur went off with him, casting back a longing look on Lucy's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: face, which lay in her pillow, almost whiter than the lawn. She lay
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: quite still, and I looked round the room to see that all was as it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: should be. I could see that the Professor had carried out in this room,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as in the other, his purpose of using the garlic; the whole of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: window-sashes reeked with it, and round Lucy's neck, over the silk
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: her face was at its worst, for the open mouth showed the pale gums. Her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: teeth, in the dim, uncertain light, seemed longer and sharper than they
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had been in the morning. In particular, by some trick of the light, the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: canine teeth looked longer and sharper than the rest. I sat down by her,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and presently she moved uneasily. At the same moment there came a sort
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of dull flapping or buffeting at the window. I went over to it softly,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and peeped out by the corner of the blind. There was a full moonlight,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and I could see that the noise was made by a great bat, which wheeled
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: round--doubtless attracted by the light, although so dim--and every now
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and again struck the window with its wings. When I came back to my seat,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I found that Lucy had moved slightly, and had torn away the garlic
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: flowers from her throat. I replaced them as well as I could, and sat
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: watching her.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Presently she woke, and I gave her food, as Van Helsing had prescribed.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: She took but a little, and that languidly. There did not seem to be with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: her now the unconscious struggle for life and strength that had hitherto
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so marked her illness. It struck me as curious that the moment she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: became conscious she pressed the garlic flowers close to her. It was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: certainly odd that whenever she got into that lethargic state, with the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stertorous breathing, she put the flowers from her; but that when she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: waked she clutched them close. There was no possibility of making any
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mistake about this, for in the long hours that followed, she had many
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: spells of sleeping and waking and repeated both actions many times.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: At six o'clock Van Helsing came to relieve me. Arthur had then fallen
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: into a doze, and he mercifully let him sleep on. When he saw Lucy's face

title: Dracula

text: I could hear the sissing indraw of his breath, and he said to me in a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and, with his face almost touching Lucy's, examined her carefully. He
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: removed the flowers and lifted the silk handkerchief from her throat. As
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he did so he started back, and I could hear his ejaculation, "Mein
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Gott!" as it was smothered in his throat. I bent over and looked, too,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and as I noticed some queer chill came over me.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The wounds on the throat had absolutely disappeared.
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: let him come and see the last; he trusts us, and we have promised him."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hands, and slid down on his knees by the sofa, where he remained,

text: perhaps a minute, with his head buried, praying, whilst his shoulders

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: When we came into Lucy's room I could see that Van Helsing had, with
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his usual forethought, been putting matters straight and making
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hair, so that it lay on the pillow in its usual sunny ripples. When we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: softly:--
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

text: yet! Hold her hand; it will comfort her more."
author: Stoker, Bram

text: So Arthur took her hand and knelt beside her, and she looked her best,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with all the soft lines matching the angelic beauty of her eyes. Then
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gradually her eyes closed, and she sank to sleep. For a little bit her
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: And then insensibly there came the strange change which I had noticed in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the night. Her breathing grew stertorous, the mouth opened, and the pale
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: gums, drawn back, made the teeth look longer and sharper than ever. In a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: were now dull and hard at once, and said in a soft, voluptuous voice,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: such as I had never heard from her lips:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Arthur! Oh, my love, I am so glad you have come! Kiss me!" Arthur bent
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had been startled by her voice, swooped upon him, and catching him by
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the neck with both hands, dragged him back with a fury of strength which
author: Stoker, Bram

text: I never thought he could have possessed, and actually hurled him almost

title: Dracula

text: across the room.
author: Stoker, Bram

text: "Not for your life!" he said; "not for your living soul and hers!" And
author: Stoker, Bram

text: he stood between them like a lion at bay.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Arthur was so taken aback that he did not for a moment know what to do

title: Dracula

text: or say; and before any impulse of violence could seize him he realised
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the place and the occasion, and stood silent, waiting.

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of rage flit like a shadow over her face; the sharp teeth champed
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: putting out her poor, pale, thin hand, took Van Helsing's great brown
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: one; drawing it to her, she kissed it. "My true friend," she said, in a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: guard him, and give me peace!"

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

text: I took Arthur by the arm, and led him away to the drawing-room, where he
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

text: "But why do it at all? The girl is dead. Why mutilate her poor body

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Friend John, I pity your poor bleeding heart; and I love you the more
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that you do bear. But there are things that you know not, but that you
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shall know, and bless me for knowing, though they are not pleasant
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: things. John, my child, you have been my friend now many years, and yet
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: oh! so lonely when I want all help and courage that may be!" He paused a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: him:--

text: "And now, Arthur my friend, dear lad, am I not forgiven?"
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in his, and raising it to his lips, pressed it, and said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

text: Before we moved away Van Helsing said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

text: to ourselves. But there remains a greater task: to find out the author
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of all this our sorrow and to stamp him out. I have clues which we can
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: follow; but it is a long task, and a difficult, and there is danger in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it, and pain. Shall you not all help me? We have learned to believe, all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of us--is it not so? And since so, do we not see our duty? Yes! And do
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the clock with friend John. I shall entreat two others, two that you
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: know not as yet; and I shall be ready to all our work show and our plans

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

text: The Professor was delighted. "Ah, that wonderful Madam Mina," he said,
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: copy of it, as also of Mrs. Harker's diary at Whitby. "Take these," he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: said, "and study them well. When I have returned you will be master of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all the facts, and we can then better enter on our inquisition. Keep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them safe, for there is in them much of treasure. You will need all your
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is here told," he laid his hand heavily and gravely on the packet of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: papers as he spoke, "may be the beginning of the end to you and me and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: many another; or it may sound the knell of the Un-Dead who walk the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: earth. Read all, I pray you, with the open mind; and if you can add in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: any way to the story here told do so, for it is all-important. You have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: kept diary of all these so strange things; is it not so? Yes! Then we
author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

text: when we entered.

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

text: _29 September._--After I had tidied myself, I went down to Dr. Seward's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: study. At the door I paused a moment, for I thought I heard him talking
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with some one. As, however, he had pressed me to be quick, I knocked at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the door, and on his calling out, "Come in," I entered.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: To my intense surprise, there was no one with him. He was quite alone,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: interested.
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

text: as I heard you talking, and thought there was some one with you."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Oh," he replied with a smile, "I was only entering my diary."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Your diary?" I asked him in surprise.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Yes," he answered. "I keep it in this." As he spoke he laid his hand on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the phonograph. I felt quite excited over it, and blurted out:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Why, this beats even shorthand! May I hear it say something?"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Certainly," he replied with alacrity, and stood up to put it in train
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for speaking. Then he paused, and a troubled look overspread his face.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "The fact is," he began awkwardly, "I only keep my diary in it; and as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it is entirely--almost entirely--about my cases, it may be awkward--that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is, I mean----" He stopped, and I tried to help him out of his
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: embarrassment:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "You helped to attend dear Lucy at the end. Let me hear how she died;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: To my surprise, he answered, with a horrorstruck look in his face:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Tell you of her death? Not for the wide world!"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Why not?" I asked, for some grave, terrible feeling was coming over me.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Again he paused, and I could see that he was trying to invent an excuse.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: diary." Even while he was speaking an idea dawned upon him, and he said
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with unconscious simplicity, in a different voice, and with the naïveté
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of a child: "That's quite true, upon my honour. Honest Indian!" I could
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not but smile, at which he grimaced. "I gave myself away that time!" he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: said. "But do you know that, although I have kept the diary for months
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: past, it never once struck me how I was going to find any particular
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: part of it in case I wanted to look it up?" By this time my mind was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: made up that the diary of a doctor who attended Lucy might have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: story!"
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: better. I have not faltered in giving every thought of my own heart in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this cause; but, of course, you do not know me--yet; and I must not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: expect you to trust me so far."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: him. He stood up and opened a large drawer, in which were arranged in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: order a number of hollow cylinders of metal covered with dark wax, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: said:--
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

text: _29 September._--I was so absorbed in that wonderful diary of Jonathan
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Harker and that other of his wife that I let the time run on without
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thinking. Mrs. Harker was not down when the maid came to announce
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: she came in. She looked sweetly pretty, but very sad, and her eyes were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: now the sight of those sweet eyes, brightened with recent tears, went
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

text: "I greatly fear I have distressed you."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Oh, no, not distressed me," she replied, "but I have been more touched
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: than I can say by your grief. That is a wonderful machine, but it is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cruelly true. It told me, in its very tones, the anguish of your heart.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: It was like a soul crying out to Almighty God. No one must hear them
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: spoken ever again! See, I have tried to be useful. I have copied out the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: words on my typewriter, and none other need now hear your heart beat, as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I did."
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: laid her hand on mine and said very gravely:--
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: death and all that led to it; because in the struggle which we have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: before us to rid the earth of this terrible monster we must have all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the knowledge and all the help which we can get. I think that the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: out. Jonathan and I have been working day and night since Professor Van
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
