text: low-spirited to-day. I suppose it is the reaction from the terrible
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: excitement.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Last night I went to bed when the men had gone, simply because they told
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me to. I didn't feel sleepy, and I did feel full of devouring anxiety. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: kept thinking over everything that has been ever since Jonathan came to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: see me in London, and it all seems like a horrible tragedy, with fate
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pressing on relentlessly to some destined end. Everything that one does
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seems, no matter how right it may be, to bring on the very thing which
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is most to be deplored. If I hadn't gone to Whitby, perhaps poor dear
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Lucy would be with us now. She hadn't taken to visiting the churchyard
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: till I came, and if she hadn't come there in the day-time with me she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wouldn't have walked there in her sleep; and if she hadn't gone there at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night and asleep, that monster couldn't have destroyed her as he did.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Oh, why did I ever go to Whitby? There now, crying again! I wonder what
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: has come over me to-day. I must hide it from Jonathan, for if he knew
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that I had been crying twice in one morning--I, who never cried on my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: own account, and whom he has never caused to shed a tear--the dear
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fellow would fret his heart out. I shall put a bold face on, and if I do
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: feel weepy, he shall never see it. I suppose it is one of the lessons
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that we poor women have to learn....
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I can't quite remember how I fell asleep last night. I remember hearing
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the sudden barking of the dogs and a lot of queer sounds, like praying
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: on a very tumultuous scale, from Mr. Renfield's room, which is somewhere
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: under this. And then there was silence over everything, silence so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: profound that it startled me, and I got up and looked out of the window.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: All was dark and silent, the black shadows thrown by the moonlight
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: seeming full of a silent mystery of their own. Not a thing seemed to be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stirring, but all to be grim and fixed as death or fate; so that a thin
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: streak of white mist, that crept with almost imperceptible slowness
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: across the grass towards the house, seemed to have a sentience and a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: vitality of its own. I think that the digression of my thoughts must
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have done me good, for when I got back to bed I found a lethargy
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: creeping over me. I lay a while, but could not quite sleep, so I got out
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and looked out of the window again. The mist was spreading, and was now
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: close up to the house, so that I could see it lying thick against the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wall, as though it were stealing up to the windows. The poor man was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: more loud than ever, and though I could not distinguish a word he said,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I could in some way recognise in his tones some passionate entreaty on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: his part. Then there was the sound of a struggle, and I knew that the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: attendants were dealing with him. I was so frightened that I crept into
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: bed, and pulled the clothes over my head, putting my fingers in my ears.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I was not then a bit sleepy, at least so I thought; but I must have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fallen asleep, for, except dreams, I do not remember anything until the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: morning, when Jonathan woke me. I think that it took me an effort and a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: little time to realise where I was, and that it was Jonathan who was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: bending over me. My dream was very peculiar, and was almost typical of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the way that waking thoughts become merged in, or continued in, dreams.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I thought that I was asleep, and waiting for Jonathan to come back. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was very anxious about him, and I was powerless to act; my feet, and my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hands, and my brain were weighted, so that nothing could proceed at the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: usual pace. And so I slept uneasily and thought. Then it began to dawn
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: upon me that the air was heavy, and dank, and cold. I put back the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: clothes from my face, and found, to my surprise, that all was dim
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: around. The gaslight which I had left lit for Jonathan, but turned down,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: came only like a tiny red spark through the fog, which had evidently
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: grown thicker and poured into the room. Then it occurred to me that I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had shut the window before I had come to bed. I would have got out to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: make certain on the point, but some leaden lethargy seemed to chain my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: limbs and even my will. I lay still and endured; that was all. I closed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my eyes, but could still see through my eyelids. (It is wonderful what
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: tricks our dreams play us, and how conveniently we can imagine.) The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: mist grew thicker and thicker and I could see now how it came in, for I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could see it like smoke--or with the white energy of boiling
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: water--pouring in, not through the window, but through the joinings of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the door. It got thicker and thicker, till it seemed as if it became
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: concentrated into a sort of pillar of cloud in the room, through the top
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of which I could see the light of the gas shining like a red eye. Things
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: began to whirl through my brain just as the cloudy column was now
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: whirling in the room, and through it all came the scriptural words "a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pillar of cloud by day and of fire by night." Was it indeed some such
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: spiritual guidance that was coming to me in my sleep? But the pillar was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: composed of both the day and the night-guiding, for the fire was in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: red eye, which at the thought got a new fascination for me; till, as I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: looked, the fire divided, and seemed to shine on me through the fog like
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: two red eyes, such as Lucy told me of in her momentary mental wandering
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: when, on the cliff, the dying sunlight struck the windows of St. Mary's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Church. Suddenly the horror burst upon me that it was thus that Jonathan
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: had seen those awful women growing into reality through the whirling mist
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in the moonlight, and in my dream I must have fainted, for all became
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: black darkness. The last conscious effort which imagination made was to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: show me a livid white face bending over me out of the mist. I must be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: careful of such dreams, for they would unseat one's reason if there were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: too much of them. I would get Dr. Van Helsing or Dr. Seward to prescribe
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: something for me which would make me sleep, only that I fear to alarm
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them. Such a dream at the present time would become woven into their
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fears for me. To-night I shall strive hard to sleep naturally. If I do
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not, I shall to-morrow night get them to give me a dose of chloral; that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cannot hurt me for once, and it will give me a good night's sleep. Last
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night tired me more than if I had not slept at all.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _2 October 10 p. m._--Last night I slept, but did not dream. I must have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: slept soundly, for I was not waked by Jonathan coming to bed; but the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sleep has not refreshed me, for to-day I feel terribly weak and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: spiritless. I spent all yesterday trying to read, or lying down dozing.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: In the afternoon Mr. Renfield asked if he might see me. Poor man, he was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: very gentle, and when I came away he kissed my hand and bade God bless
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me. Some way it affected me much; I am crying when I think of him. This
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is a new weakness, of which I must be careful. Jonathan would be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: miserable if he knew I had been crying. He and the others were out till
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dinner-time, and they all came in tired. I did what I could to brighten
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them up, and I suppose that the effort did me good, for I forgot how
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: tired I was. After dinner they sent me to bed, and all went off to smoke
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: together, as they said, but I knew that they wanted to tell each other
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of what had occurred to each during the day; I could see from Jonathan's
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: manner that he had something important to communicate. I was not so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sleepy as I should have been; so before they went I asked Dr. Seward to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: give me a little opiate of some kind, as I had not slept well the night
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: before. He very kindly made me up a sleeping draught, which he gave to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me, telling me that it would do me no harm, as it was very mild.... I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have taken it, and am waiting for sleep, which still keeps aloof. I hope
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I have not done wrong, for as sleep begins to flirt with me, a new fear
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: comes: that I may have been foolish in thus depriving myself of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: power of waking. I might want it. Here comes sleep. Good-night.
author: Stoker, Bram

text: _1 October, evening._--I found Thomas Snelling in his house at Bethnal
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Green, but unhappily he was not in a condition to remember anything. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: proved too much, and he had begun too early on his expected debauch. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: learned, however, from his wife, who seemed a decent, poor soul, that he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was only the assistant to Smollet, who of the two mates was the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: responsible person. So off I drove to Walworth, and found Mr. Joseph
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Smollet at home and in his shirtsleeves, taking a late tea out of a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: saucer. He is a decent, intelligent fellow, distinctly a good, reliable
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: type of workman, and with a headpiece of his own. He remembered all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: about the incident of the boxes, and from a wonderful dog's-eared
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: notebook, which he produced from some mysterious receptacle about the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: half-obliterated pencil, he gave me the destinations of the boxes. There
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: were, he said, six in the cartload which he took from Carfax and left at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: 197, Chicksand Street, Mile End New Town, and another six which he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: deposited at Jamaica Lane, Bermondsey. If then the Count meant to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: scatter these ghastly refuges of his over London, these places were
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: chosen as the first of delivery, so that later he might distribute more
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fully. The systematic manner in which this was done made me think that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he could not mean to confine himself to two sides of London. He was now
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fixed on the far east of the northern shore, on the east of the southern
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shore, and on the south. The north and west were surely never meant to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be left out of his diabolical scheme--let alone the City itself and the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: very heart of fashionable London in the south-west and west. I went back
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to Smollet, and asked him if he could tell us if any other boxes had
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: been taken from Carfax.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: He replied:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Well, guv'nor, you've treated me wery 'an'some"--I had given him half a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sovereign--"an' I'll tell yer all I know. I heard a man by the name of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Bloxam say four nights ago in the 'Are an' 'Ounds, in Pincher's Alley,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: as 'ow he an' his mate 'ad 'ad a rare dusty job in a old 'ouse at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Purfect. There ain't a-many such jobs as this 'ere, an' I'm thinkin'
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that maybe Sam Bloxam could tell ye summut." I asked if he could tell me
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: where to find him. I told him that if he could get me the address it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: would be worth another half-sovereign to him. So he gulped down the rest

title: Dracula

text: of his tea and stood up, saying that he was going to begin the search

title: Dracula

text: then and there. At the door he stopped, and said:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Look 'ere, guv'nor, there ain't no sense in me a-keepin' you 'ere. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: may find Sam soon, or I mayn't; but anyhow he ain't like to be in a way
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to tell ye much to-night. Sam is a rare one when he starts on the booze.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: If you can give me a envelope with a stamp on it, and put yer address on

title: Dracula

text: it, I'll find out where Sam is to be found and post it ye to-night. But
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: ye'd better be up arter 'im soon in the mornin', or maybe ye won't ketch
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: 'im; for Sam gets off main early, never mind the booze the night afore."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: buy an envelope and a sheet of paper, and to keep the change. When she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: to home. We're on the track anyhow. I am tired to-night, and want sleep.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: but that, when I should return from this new search, I would arrange for

title: Dracula

text: with her daily tasks to interest her, than in being here amongst us and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

text: _3 October._--The time seemed terrible long whilst we were waiting for
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the coming of Godalming and Quincey Morris. The Professor tried to keep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: our minds active by using them all the time. I could see his beneficent
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: purpose, by the side glances which he threw from time to time at Harker.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: The poor fellow is overwhelmed in a misery that is appalling to see.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Last night he was a frank, happy-looking man, with strong, youthful
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: face, full of energy, and with dark brown hair. To-day he is a drawn,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: haggard old man, whose white hair matches well with the hollow burning
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: eyes and grief-written lines of his face. His energy is still intact; in
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fact, he is like a living flame. This may yet be his salvation, for, if
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all go well, it will tide him over the despairing period; he will then,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in a kind of way, wake again to the realities of life. Poor fellow, I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: thought my own trouble was bad enough, but his----! The Professor knows
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this well enough, and is doing his best to keep his mind active. What he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: has been saying was, under the circumstances, of absorbing interest. So
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: well as I can remember, here it is:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "I have studied, over and over again since they came into my hands, all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the papers relating to this monster; and the more I have studied, the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: greater seems the necessity to utterly stamp him out. All through there
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: are signs of his advance; not only of his power, but of his knowledge of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: it. As I learned from the researches of my friend Arminus of Buda-Pesth,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he was in life a most wonderful man. Soldier, statesman, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: alchemist--which latter was the highest development of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: science-knowledge of his time. He had a mighty brain, a learning beyond
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: compare, and a heart that knew no fear and no remorse. He dared even to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: attend the Scholomance, and there was no branch of knowledge of his time
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that he did not essay. Well, in him the brain powers survived the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: physical death; though it would seem that memory was not all complete.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: In some faculties of mind he has been, and is, only a child; but he is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: growing, and some things that were childish at the first are now of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: man's stature. He is experimenting, and doing it well; and if it had not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: been that we have crossed his path he would be yet--he may be yet if we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: fail--the father or furtherer of a new order of beings, whose road must
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lead through Death, not Life."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Harker groaned and said, "And this is all arrayed against my darling!
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: But how is he experimenting? The knowledge may help us to defeat him!"
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "He has all along, since his coming, been trying his power, slowly but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: surely; that big child-brain of his is working. Well for us, it is, as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: yet, a child-brain; for had he dared, at the first, to attempt certain
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: things he would long ago have been beyond our power. However, he means
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to succeed, and a man who has centuries before him can afford to wait
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and to go slow. _Festina lente_ may well be his motto."
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: Carpathians. We have no fear in running at good speed up the river at
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night; there is plenty of water, and the banks are wide enough apart to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: make steaming, even in the dark, easy enough. Lord Godalming tells me to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sleep for a while, as it is enough for the present for one to be on
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: watch. But I cannot sleep--how can I with the terrible danger hanging
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: over my darling, and her going out into that awful place.... My only
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: comfort is that we are in the hands of God. Only for that faith it would
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: be easier to die than to live, and so be quit of all the trouble. Mr.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Morris and Dr. Seward were off on their long ride before we started;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: they are to keep up the right bank, far enough off to get on higher
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: lands where they can see a good stretch of river and avoid the following
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of its curves. They have, for the first stages, two men to ride and lead
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: their spare horses--four in all, so as not to excite curiosity. When
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: they dismiss the men, which shall be shortly, they shall themselves look
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: after the horses. It may be necessary for us to join forces; if so they
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: can mount our whole party. One of the saddles has a movable horn, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: can be easily adapted for Mina, if required.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: It is a wild adventure we are on. Here, as we are rushing along through
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: the darkness, with the cold from the river seeming to rise up and strike
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: us; with all the mysterious voices of the night around us, it all comes
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: home. We seem to be drifting into unknown places and unknown ways; into
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a whole world of dark and dreadful things. Godalming is shutting the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: furnace door....
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _31 October._--Still hurrying along. The day has come, and Godalming is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sleeping. I am on watch. The morning is bitterly cold; the furnace heat
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: is grateful, though we have heavy fur coats. As yet we have passed only
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: a few open boats, but none of them had on board any box or package of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: anything like the size of the one we seek. The men were scared every
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: time we turned our electric lamp on them, and fell on their knees and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: prayed.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _1 November, evening._--No news all day; we have found nothing of the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: kind we seek. We have now passed into the Bistritza; and if we are wrong
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: in our surmise our chance is gone. We have over-hauled every boat, big
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and little. Early this morning, one crew took us for a Government boat,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and treated us accordingly. We saw in this a way of smoothing matters,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so at Fundu, where the Bistritza runs into the Sereth, we got a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Roumanian flag which we now fly conspicuously. With every boat which we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have over-hauled since then this trick has succeeded; we have had every
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: deference shown to us, and not once any objection to whatever we chose
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to ask or do. Some of the Slovaks tell us that a big boat passed them,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: going at more than usual speed as she had a double crew on board. This
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was before they came to Fundu, so they could not tell us whether the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: boat turned into the Bistritza or continued on up the Sereth. At Fundu
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we could not hear of any such boat, so she must have passed there in the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night. I am feeling very sleepy; the cold is perhaps beginning to tell
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: upon me, and nature must have rest some time. Godalming insists that he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: shall keep the first watch. God bless him for all his goodness to poor
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: dear Mina and me.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _2 November, morning._--It is broad daylight. That good fellow would not
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wake me. He says it would have been a sin to, for I slept peacefully and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: was forgetting my trouble. It seems brutally selfish to me to have slept
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so long, and let him watch all night; but he was quite right. I am a new
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: man this morning; and, as I sit here and watch him sleeping, I can do
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: all that is necessary both as to minding the engine, steering, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: keeping watch. I can feel that my strength and energy are coming back to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me. I wonder where Mina is now, and Van Helsing. They should have got to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Veresti about noon on Wednesday. It would take them some time to get the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: carriage and horses; so if they had started and travelled hard, they
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: would be about now at the Borgo Pass. God guide and help them! I am
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: afraid to think what may happen. If we could only go faster! but we
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: cannot; the engines are throbbing and doing their utmost. I wonder how
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris are getting on. There seem to be endless
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: streams running down the mountains into this river, but as none of them
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: are very large--at present, at all events, though they are terrible
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: doubtless in winter and when the snow melts--the horsemen may not have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: met much obstruction. I hope that before we get to Strasba we may see
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: them; for if by that time we have not overtaken the Count, it may be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: necessary to take counsel together what to do next.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Dr. Seward's Diary._
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _2 November._--Three days on the road. No news, and no time to write it
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: if there had been, for every moment is precious. We have had only the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: rest needful for the horses; but we are both bearing it wonderfully.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Those adventurous days of ours are turning up useful. We must push on;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we shall never feel happy till we get the launch in sight again.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _3 November._--We heard at Fundu that the launch had gone up the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Bistritza. I wish it wasn't so cold. There are signs of snow coming; and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: if it falls heavy it will stop us. In such case we must get a sledge and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: go on, Russian fashion.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _4 November._--To-day we heard of the launch having been detained by an
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: accident when trying to force a way up the rapids. The Slovak boats get
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: up all right, by aid of a rope and steering with knowledge. Some went up
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: only a few hours before. Godalming is an amateur fitter himself, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: evidently it was he who put the launch in trim again. Finally, they got
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: up the rapids all right, with local help, and are off on the chase
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: afresh. I fear that the boat is not any better for the accident; the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: peasantry tell us that after she got upon smooth water again, she kept
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: stopping every now and again so long as she was in sight. We must push
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: on harder than ever; our help may be wanted soon.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Mina Harker's Journal._
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _31 October._--Arrived at Veresti at noon. The Professor tells me that
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this morning at dawn he could hardly hypnotise me at all, and that all I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: could say was: "dark and quiet." He is off now buying a carriage and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: horses. He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that we may be able to change them on the way. We have something more
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: than 70 miles before us. The country is lovely, and most interesting; if
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: only we were under different conditions, how delightful it would be to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: see it all. If Jonathan and I were driving through it alone what a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: pleasure it would be. To stop and see people, and learn something of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: their life, and to fill our minds and memories with all the colour and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: people! But, alas!--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _Later._--Dr. Van Helsing has returned. He has got the carriage and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: horses; we are to have some dinner, and to start in an hour. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: landlady is putting us up a huge basket of provisions; it seems enough
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: for a company of soldiers. The Professor encourages her, and whispers to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: me that it may be a week before we can get any good food again. He has
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: been shopping too, and has sent home such a wonderful lot of fur coats
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and wraps, and all sorts of warm things. There will not be any chance of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: our being cold.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: We shall soon be off. I am afraid to think what may happen to us. We are
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: truly in the hands of God. He alone knows what may be, and I pray Him,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: with all the strength of my sad and humble soul, that He will watch over
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: my beloved husband; that whatever may happen, Jonathan may know that I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: loved him and honoured him more than I can say, and that my latest and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: truest thought will be always for him.

author: Stoker, Bram

text: _1 November._--All day long we have travelled, and at a good speed. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: horses seem to know that they are being kindly treated, for they go
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: willingly their full stage at best speed. We have now had so many
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: changes and find the same thing so constantly that we are encouraged to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: think that the journey will be an easy one. Dr. Van Helsing is laconic;
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he tells the farmers that he is hurrying to Bistritz, and pays them well
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to make the exchange of horses. We get hot soup, or coffee, or tea; and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: off we go. It is a lovely country; full of beauties of all imaginable
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: kinds, and the people are brave, and strong, and simple, and seem full
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: of nice qualities. They are _very, very_ superstitious. In the first
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: house where we stopped, when the woman who served us saw the scar on my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: forehead, she crossed herself and put out two fingers towards me, to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: keep off the evil eye. I believe they went to the trouble of putting an
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: extra amount of garlic into our food; and I can't abide garlic. Ever
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: since then I have taken care not to take off my hat or veil, and so have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: escaped their suspicions. We are travelling fast, and as we have no
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: driver with us to carry tales, we go ahead of scandal; but I daresay
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that fear of the evil eye will follow hard behind us all the way. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Professor seems tireless; all day he would not take any rest, though he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: made me sleep for a long spell. At sunset time he hypnotised me, and he
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: says that I answered as usual "darkness, lapping water and creaking
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: wood"; so our enemy is still on the river. I am afraid to think of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Jonathan, but somehow I have now no fear for him, or for myself. I write
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: this whilst we wait in a farmhouse for the horses to be got ready. Dr.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing is sleeping, Poor dear, he looks very tired and old and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: grey, but his mouth is set as firmly as a conqueror's; even in his sleep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: he is instinct with resolution. When we have well started I must make
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: him rest whilst I drive. I shall tell him that we have days before us,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and we must not break down when most of all his strength will be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: needed.... All is ready; we are off shortly.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _2 November, morning._--I was successful, and we took turns driving all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: night; now the day is on us, bright though cold. There is a strange
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: heaviness in the air--I say heaviness for want of a better word; I mean
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that it oppresses us both. It is very cold, and only our warm furs keep
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: us comfortable. At dawn Van Helsing hypnotised me; he says I answered
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "darkness, creaking wood and roaring water," so the river is changing as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: they ascend. I do hope that my darling will not run any chance of
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: danger--more than need be; but we are in God's hands.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: _2 November, night._--All day long driving. The country gets wilder as
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we go, and the great spurs of the Carpathians, which at Veresti seemed
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so far from us and so low on the horizon, now seem to gather round us
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and tower in front. We both seem in good spirits; I think we make an
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: effort each to cheer the other; in the doing so we cheer ourselves. Dr.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing says that by morning we shall reach the Borgo Pass. The
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: houses are very few here now, and the Professor says that the last horse
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: we got will have to go on with us, as we may not be able to change. He
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: got two in addition to the two we changed, so that now we have a rude
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: four-in-hand. The dear horses are patient and good, and they give us no
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: trouble. We are not worried with other travellers, and so even I can
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: drive. We shall get to the Pass in daylight; we do not want to arrive
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: before. So we take it easy, and have each a long rest in turn. Oh, what
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: will to-morrow bring to us? We go to seek the place where my poor
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: darling suffered so much. God grant that we may be guided aright, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: that He will deign to watch over my husband and those dear to us both,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and who are in such deadly peril. As for me, I am not worthy in His
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sight. Alas! I am unclean to His eyes, and shall be until He may deign
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: to let me stand forth in His sight as one of those who have not incurred
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: His wrath.
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Purfleet, London, in case I may not see him. It may explain. It is
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: morning, and I write by a fire which all the night I have kept
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: alive--Madam Mina aiding me. It is cold, cold; so cold that the grey
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: heavy sky is full of snow, which when it falls will settle for all
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: winter as the ground is hardening to receive it. It seems to have
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: affected Madam Mina; she has been so heavy of head all day that she was
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not like herself. She sleeps, and sleeps, and sleeps! She who is usual
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: so alert, have done literally nothing all the day; she even have lost
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: her appetite. She make no entry into her little diary, she who write so
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: faithful at every pause. Something whisper to me that all is not well.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: However, to-night she is more _vif_. Her long sleep all day have refresh
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: and restore her, for now she is all sweet and bright as ever. At sunset
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: I try to hypnotise her, but alas! with no effect; the power has grown
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: less and less with each day, and to-night it fail me altogether. Well,
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: God's will be done--whatever it may be, and whithersoever it may lead!
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Now to the historical, for as Madam Mina write not in her stenography, I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: must, in my cumbrous old fashion, that so each day of us may not go
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: unrecorded.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: We got to the Borgo Pass just after sunrise yesterday morning. When I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: saw the signs of the dawn I got ready for the hypnotism. We stopped our
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: carriage, and got down so that there might be no disturbance. I made a
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: couch with furs, and Madam Mina, lying down, yield herself as usual, but
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: more slow and more short time than ever, to the hypnotic sleep. As
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: before, came the answer: "darkness and the swirling of water." Then she
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: woke, bright and radiant and we go on our way and soon reach the Pass.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: At this time and place, she become all on fire with zeal; some new
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: guiding power be in her manifested, for she point to a road and say:--
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "This is the way."
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "How know you it?" I ask.
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: "Of course I know it," she answer, and with a pause, add: "Have not my
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: Jonathan travelled it and wrote of his travel?"
author: Stoker, Bram

text: At first I think somewhat strange, but soon I see that there be only one
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: such by-road. It is used but little, and very different from the coach
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: road from the Bukovina to Bistritz, which is more wide and hard, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: more of use.
author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: sure that they were roads at all, for they be neglect and light snow
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have fallen--the horses know and they only. I give rein to them, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: they go on so patient. By-and-by we find all the things which Jonathan
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: have note in that wonderful diary of him. Then we go on for long, long
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: hours and hours. At the first, I tell Madam Mina to sleep; she try, and
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: she succeed. She sleep all the time; till at the last, I feel myself to
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: suspicious grow, and attempt to wake her. But she sleep on, and I may
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: not wake her though I try. I do not wish to try too hard lest I harm
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: her; for I know that she have suffer much, and sleep at times be
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: guilt, as though I have done something; I find myself bolt up, with the
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: reins in my hand, and the good horses go along jog, jog, just as ever. I
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: look down and find Madam Mina still sleep. It is now not far off sunset
author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

text: time, and over the snow the light of the sun flow in big yellow flood,

text: will tell you everything. But my story is simply one of bewilderment and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: darkness. I know absolutely nothing. Put any question you please, but
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: you know, of course, the limitations mamma has placed me under."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Perfectly, my dear child. I need not approach the topics on which she
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: desires our silence. Now, the marvel of last night consists in your
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: having been removed from your bed and your room, without being wakened,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: and this removal having occurred apparently while the windows were still
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: secured, and the two doors locked upon the inside. I will tell you my
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: theory and ask you a question."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Carmilla was leaning on her hand dejectedly; Madame and I were
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: listening breathlessly.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Now, my question is this. Have you ever been suspected of walking in
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: your sleep?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Never, since I was very young indeed."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "But you did walk in your sleep when you were young?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Yes; I know I did. I have been told so often by my old nurse."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: My father smiled and nodded.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Well, what has happened is this. You got up in your sleep, unlocked the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: door, not leaving the key, as usual, in the lock, but taking it out and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: locking it on the outside; you again took the key out, and carried it
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: away with you to some one of the five-and-twenty rooms on this floor, or
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: perhaps upstairs or downstairs. There are so many rooms and closets, so
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: much heavy furniture, and such accumulations of lumber, that it would
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: require a week to search this old house thoroughly. Do you see, now,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: what I mean?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "I do, but not all," she answered.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "And how, papa, do you account for her finding herself on the sofa in
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: the dressing room, which we had searched so carefully?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "She came there after you had searched it, still in her sleep, and at
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: last awoke spontaneously, and was as much surprised to find herself
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: where she was as any one else. I wish all mysteries were as easily and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: innocently explained as yours, Carmilla," he said, laughing. "And so we
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: may congratulate ourselves on the certainty that the most natural
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: explanation of the occurrence is one that involves no drugging, no
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: tampering with locks, no burglars, or poisoners, or witches--nothing
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: that need alarm Carmilla, or anyone else, for our safety."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Carmilla was looking charmingly. Nothing could be more beautiful than
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: her tints. Her beauty was, I think, enhanced by that graceful languor
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: that was peculiar to her. I think my father was silently contrasting her
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: looks with mine, for he said:
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "I wish my poor Laura was looking more like herself"; and he sighed.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: So our alarms were happily ended, and Carmilla restored to her friends.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

text: IX
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: _The Doctor_
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: As Carmilla would not hear of an attendant sleeping in her room, my
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: father arranged that a servant should sleep outside her door, so that
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: she would not attempt to make another such excursion without being
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: arrested at her own door.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: That night passed quietly; and next morning early, the doctor, whom my
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: father had sent for without telling me a word about it, arrived to
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: see me.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Madame accompanied me to the library; and there the grave little doctor,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: with white hair and spectacles, whom I mentioned before, was waiting to
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: receive me.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: I told him my story, and as I proceeded he grew graver and graver.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: We were standing, he and I, in the recess of one of the windows, facing
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: one another. When my statement was over, he leaned with his shoulders
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: against the wall, and with his eyes fixed on me earnestly, with an
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: interest in which was a dash of horror.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: After a minute's reflection, he asked Madame if he could see my father.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: He was sent for accordingly, and as he entered, smiling, he said:
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "I dare say, doctor, you are going to tell me that I am an old fool for
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: having brought you here; I hope I am."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: But his smile faded into shadow as the doctor, with a very grave face,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: beckoned him to him.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: He and the doctor talked for some time in the same recess where I had
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: just conferred with the physician. It seemed an earnest and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: argumentative conversation. The room is very large, and I and Madame
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: stood together, burning with curiosity, at the farther end. Not a word
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: could we hear, however, for they spoke in a very low tone, and the deep
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: recess of the window quite concealed the doctor from view, and very
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: nearly my father, whose foot, arm, and shoulder only could we see; and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: the voices were, I suppose, all the less audible for the sort of closet
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: which the thick wall and window formed.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: After a time my father's face looked into the room; it was pale,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: thoughtful, and, I fancied, agitated.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Laura, dear, come here for a moment. Madame, we shan't trouble you, the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: doctor says, at present."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Accordingly I approached, for the first time a little alarmed; for,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: although I felt very weak, I did not feel ill; and strength, one always
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: fancies, is a thing that may be picked up when we please.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: My father held out his hand to me, as I drew near, but he was looking at
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: the doctor, and he said:
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "It certainly is very odd; I don't understand it quite. Laura, come
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: here, dear; now attend to Doctor Spielsberg, and recollect yourself."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "You mentioned a sensation like that of two needles piercing the skin,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: somewhere about your neck, on the night when you experienced your first
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: horrible dream. Is there still any soreness?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "None at all," I answered.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Can you indicate with your finger about the point at which you think
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: this occurred?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Very little below my throat--here," I answered.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: I wore a morning dress, which covered the place I pointed to.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Now you can satisfy yourself," said the doctor. "You won't mind your
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: papa's lowering your dress a very little. It is necessary, to detect a
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: symptom of the complaint under which you have been suffering."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: I acquiesced. It was only an inch or two below the edge of my collar.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "God bless me!--so it is," exclaimed my father, growing pale.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "You see it now with your own eyes," said the doctor, with a gloomy
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: triumph.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "What is it?" I exclaimed, beginning to be frightened.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Nothing, my dear young lady, but a small blue spot, about the size of
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: the tip of your little finger; and now," he continued, turning to papa,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "the question is what is best to be done?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Is there any danger?" I urged, in great trepidation.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "I trust not, my dear," answered the doctor. "I don't see why you should
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: not recover. I don't see why you should not begin immediately to get
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: better. That is the point at which the sense of strangulation begins?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Yes," I answered.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "And--recollect as well as you can--the same point was a kind of center
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: of that thrill which you described just now, like the current of a cold
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: stream running against you?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "It may have been; I think it was."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Ay, you see?" he added, turning to my father. "Shall I say a word to
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Madame?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Certainly," said my father.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: He called Madame to him, and said:
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "I find my young friend here far from well. It won't be of any great
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: consequence, I hope; but it will be necessary that some steps be taken,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: which I will explain by-and-by; but in the meantime, Madame, you will
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: be so good as not to let Miss Laura be alone for one moment. That is the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: only direction I need give for the present. It is indispensable."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "We may rely upon your kindness, Madame, I know," added my father.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Madame satisfied him eagerly.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "And you, dear Laura, I know you will observe the doctor's direction."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "I shall have to ask your opinion upon another patient, whose symptoms
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: slightly resemble those of my daughter, that have just been detailed to
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: you--very much milder in degree, but I believe quite of the same sort.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: She is a young lady--our guest; but as you say you will be passing this
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: way again this evening, you can't do better than take your supper here,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: and you can then see her. She does not come down till the afternoon."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "I thank you," said the doctor. "I shall be with you, then, at about
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: seven this evening."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: And then they repeated their directions to me and to Madame, and with
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: this parting charge my father left us, and walked out with the doctor;
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: and I saw them pacing together up and down between the road and the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: moat, on the grassy platform in front of the castle, evidently absorbed
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: in earnest conversation.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: The doctor did not return. I saw him mount his horse there, take his
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: leave, and ride away eastward through the forest.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Nearly at the same time I saw the man arrive from Dranfield with the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: letters, and dismount and hand the bag to my father.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: In the meantime, Madame and I were both busy, lost in conjecture as to
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: the reasons of the singular and earnest direction which the doctor and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: my father had concurred in imposing. Madame, as she afterwards told me,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: was afraid the doctor apprehended a sudden seizure, and that, without
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: prompt assistance, I might either lose my life in a fit, or at least be
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: seriously hurt.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: The interpretation did not strike me; and I fancied, perhaps luckily for
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: my nerves, that the arrangement was prescribed simply to secure a
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: companion, who would prevent my taking too much exercise, or eating
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: unripe fruit, or doing any of the fifty foolish things to which young
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: people are supposed to be prone.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: About half an hour after my father came in--he had a letter in his
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: hand--and said:
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "This letter had been delayed; it is from General Spielsdorf. He might
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: have been here yesterday, he may not come till tomorrow or he may be
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: here today."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: He put the open letter into my hand; but he did not look pleased, as he
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: used when a guest, especially one so much loved as the General,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: was coming.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: On the contrary, he looked as if he wished him at the bottom of the Red
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Sea. There was plainly something on his mind which he did not choose
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: to divulge.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Papa, darling, will you tell me this?" said I, suddenly laying my hand
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: on his arm, and looking, I am sure, imploringly in his face.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Perhaps," he answered, smoothing my hair caressingly over my eyes.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Does the doctor think me very ill?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "No, dear; he thinks, if right steps are taken, you will be quite well
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: again, at least, on the high road to a complete recovery, in a day or
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: two," he answered, a little dryly. "I wish our good friend, the General,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: had chosen any other time; that is, I wish you had been perfectly well
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: to receive him."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "But do tell me, papa," I insisted, "what does he think is the matter
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: with me?"
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Nothing; you must not plague me with questions," he answered, with more
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: irritation than I ever remember him to have displayed before; and seeing
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: that I looked wounded, I suppose, he kissed me, and added, "You shall
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: know all about it in a day or two; that is, all that I know. In the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: meantime you are not to trouble your head about it."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: He turned and left the room, but came back before I had done wondering
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: and puzzling over the oddity of all this; it was merely to say that he
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: was going to Karnstein, and had ordered the carriage to be ready at
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: twelve, and that I and Madame should accompany him; he was going to see the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: priest who lived near those picturesque grounds, upon business, and as
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Carmilla had never seen them, she could follow, when she came down, with
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Mademoiselle, who would bring materials for what you call a picnic,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: which might be laid for us in the ruined castle.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: At twelve o'clock, accordingly, I was ready, and not long after, my
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: father, Madame and I set out upon our projected drive.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Passing the drawbridge we turn to the right, and follow the road over
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: the steep Gothic bridge, westward, to reach the deserted village and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: ruined castle of Karnstein.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: No sylvan drive can be fancied prettier. The ground breaks into gentle
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: hills and hollows, all clothed with beautiful wood, totally destitute of
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: the comparative formality which artificial planting and early culture
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: and pruning impart.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: The irregularities of the ground often lead the road out of its course,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: and cause it to wind beautifully round the sides of broken hollows and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: the steeper sides of the hills, among varieties of ground almost
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: inexhaustible.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Turning one of these points, we suddenly encountered our old friend, the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: General, riding towards us, attended by a mounted servant. His
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: portmanteaus were following in a hired wagon, such as we term a cart.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: The General dismounted as we pulled up, and, after the usual greetings,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: was easily persuaded to accept the vacant seat in the carriage and send
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: his horse on with his servant to the schloss.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

text: X
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: _Bereaved_
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: It was about ten months since we had last seen him: but that time had
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: sufficed to make an alteration of years in his appearance. He had grown
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: thinner; something of gloom and anxiety had taken the place of that
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: cordial serenity which used to characterize his features. His dark blue
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: eyes, always penetrating, now gleamed with a sterner light from under
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: his shaggy grey eyebrows. It was not such a change as grief alone
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: usually induces, and angrier passions seemed to have had their share in
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: bringing it about.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: We had not long resumed our drive, when the General began to talk, with
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: his usual soldierly directness, of the bereavement, as he termed it,
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: which he had sustained in the death of his beloved niece and ward; and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: he then broke out in a tone of intense bitterness and fury, inveighing
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: against the "hellish arts" to which she had fallen a victim, and
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: expressing, with more exasperation than piety, his wonder that Heaven
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: should tolerate so monstrous an indulgence of the lusts and malignity
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: of hell.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: My father, who saw at once that something very extraordinary had
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: befallen, asked him, if not too painful to him, to detail the
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: circumstances which he thought justified the strong terms in which he
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: expressed himself.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "I should tell you all with pleasure," said the General, "but you would
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: not believe me."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Why should I not?" he asked.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Because," he answered testily, "you believe in nothing but what
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: consists with your own prejudices and illusions. I remember when I was
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: like you, but I have learned better."
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: "Try me," said my father; "I am not such a dogmatist as you suppose.
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: Besides which, I very well know that you generally require proof for
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

text: For some time the health of Clarimonde had not been so good as usual;
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: her complexion grew paler day by day. The physicians who were summoned
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: could not comprehend the nature of her malady and knew not how to treat
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: it. They all prescribed some insignificant remedies, and never called
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: a second time. Her paleness, nevertheless, visibly increased, and she
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: became colder and colder, until she seemed almost as white and dead as
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: upon that memorable night in the unknown castle. I grieved with anguish
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: unspeakable to behold her thus slowly perishing; and she, touched by my
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: agony, smiled upon me sweetly and sadly with the fateful smile of those
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: who feel that they must die.
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: One morning I was seated at her bedside, and breakfasting from a little
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: table placed close at hand, so that I might not be obliged to leave her
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: for a single instant. In the act of cutting some fruit I accidentally
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: inflicted rather a deep gash on my finger. The blood immediately gushed
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: forth in a little purple jet, and a few drops spurted upon Clarimonde.
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: Her eyes flashed, her face suddenly assumed an expression of savage and
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: ferocious joy such as I had never before observed in her. She leaped out
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: of her bed with animal agility--the agility, as it were, of an ape or a
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: cat--and sprang upon my wound, which she commenced to suck with an air
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: of unutterable pleasure. She swallowed the blood in little mouthfuls,
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: slowly and carefully, like a connoisseur tasting a wine from Xeres or
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: Syracuse. Gradually her eyelids half closed, and the pupils of her green
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: eyes became oblong instead of round. From time to time she paused in
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: the lips of the wound in order to coax forth a few more ruddy drops.
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: When she found that the blood would no longer come, she arose with eyes
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: liquid and brilliant, rosier than a May dawn; her face full and fresh,
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: her hand warm and moist--in fine, more beautiful than ever, and in the
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: most perfect health.
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: 'I shall not die! I shall not die!' she cried, clinging to my neck, half
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: mad with joy. 'I can love thee yet for a long time. My life is thine,
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: and all that is of me comes from thee. A few drops of thy rich and noble
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: have given me back life.'
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

text: This scene long haunted my memory, and inspired me with strange
author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile

text: It was the magic hour of dining. The long Digue of Heyst was almost deserted; so was the strip of loose, yellow sand which skirted its base, and all the tables d'htes were filling fast. Henri, the youngest waiter of the Htel Lion d'Or, was standing on the steps between the two great gilded lions which stood rampart on either side the portals, vigorously ringing a loud and discordant bell to summon the stragglers, whilst the ladies who were waiting the commencement of dinner in the little salon to the side stopped their ears to dull its clamour. Philippe and Jules were busy laying white cloths and glasses, etc., on the marble tables in the open balcony outside the salle à manger, where strangers to the Hotel might dine à la carte if they chose. Inside, the long narrow tables were decorated with dusty geraniums and fuchsias, whilst each cruet-stand had a small bunch of dirty artificial flowers tied to its handle. But the visitors to the Lion d'Or, who were mostly English, were too eager for their evening meal to cavil at their surroundings. The Baroness Gobelli, with her husband on one side and her son on the other, was the first to seat herself at table. The Baroness always appeared with the soup, for she had observed that the first comers received a more generous helping than those who came in last. No such anxiety occupied the minds of Mrs. Pullen and her friend Miss Leyton who sat opposite to the Baroness and her family.
