title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! Mrs. Pullen! have you seen the Baroness?" she exclaimed.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "We are going to bathe this morning. Aren't you coming down to the sands?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "No! Miss Brandt, not to-day. I am unhappy about my dear baby! I am sure you will be sorry to hear that she has been quite ill all night-so restless and feverish!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! she'll be all right directly her teeth come through!" replied Harriet indifferently, as her eyes scanned the scene before them. "There's the Baroness! She's beckoning to me! Good-bye!" and without a word of sympathy or comfort, she rushed away to join her friends.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Like the way of the world!" thought Margaret, as she watched the girl skimming over the sands, "but somehow-I didn't think she would be so heartless!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Miss Leyton and her fiancé had strolled off after breakfast to take a walk and Mrs. Pullen went back to her own room, and sat down quietly to needlework. She was becoming very anxious for Doctor Phillips' arrival; had even written to England to ask him to hurry it if possible-for her infant, though not positively ill, rejected her food so often that she was palpably thinner and weaker.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: After she had sat there for some time she took up her fieldglasses to survey the bathers on the beach. She had often done so before, when confined to the hotel-it afforded her amusement to watch their faces and antics. On the present occasion she had no difficulty in distinguishing the form of the Baroness Gobelli looking enormous as, clad in a most conspicuous bathing costume, she waddled from her machine into the water, loudly calling attention to her appearance from all assembled on the sands as she went. The Baron, looking little less comical, advanced to conduct his spouse down to the water, whilst after them flew a slight boyish figure in yellow with a mane of dark hair hanging down her back, which Margaret immediately recognised as that of Harriet Brandt.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: She was dancing about in the shallow water, shrieking whenever she made a false step and clinging hold of the Baron's hand, when Margaret saw another gentleman come up to them and join in the ring. She turned the glasses upon him and saw to her amazement that it was her brother-in-law. Her first feeling was that of annoyance. There was nothing extraordinary or improper in his joining the Baroness's party-men and women bathed promiscuously in Heyst, and no one thought anything of it. But that Ralph should voluntarily mix himself up with the Gobellis, after Elinor's particular request that he should keep aloof from them, was a much more serious matter. And by the way, that reminded her, where was Elinor the while? Margaret could not discern her anywhere upon the sands and wondered if she had also been persuaded to bathe. She watched Captain Pullen evidently trying to induce Miss Brandt to venture further into the water, holding out both hands for her protection-she also saw her yield to his persuasion and leaving go of her hold on the Herr Baron, trust herself entirely to the stranger's care. Mrs. Pullen turned from the window with a sigh. She hoped there were not going to be any "ructions" between Ralph and Elinor-but she would not have liked her to see him at that moment. She bestowed a silent benediction, "not loud, but deep"[99] on the foreign fashion of promiscuous bathing, and walked across the corridor to her friend's room to see if she had returned to the Hotel. To her surprise she found Miss Leyton dismantled of her walking attire, soberly seated at her table writing letters.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Why! Elinor," she said, "I thought you were out with Ralph!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The young lady was quite composed.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "So I was," she answered, "until half an hour ago! But as he then expressed his determination to bathe I left him to his own devices and came back to write my letters."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Would he not have preferred your waiting on the sands till he could join you again?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I did not ask him! I should think he would hardly care for me to watch him whilst bathing, and I am sure I should not consent to do so!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But everybody does it here, Elinor, and if you did not care to go down to the beach you might have waited for him on the Digue."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "My dear Margaret, I am not in the habit of dancing attendance upon men. It is their business to come after me! If Ralph is eager for another walk after his dip he can easily call for me here!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "True! and he can as easily go for his walk with any stray acquaintance he may pick up on the sands!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! if he should prefer it, he is welcome to do so," replied Elinor, resuming her scribbling.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "My dear Elinor, I don't think you quite understand Ralph! He has been terribly spoilt you know, and when men have been accustomed to attention they will take it wherever they can get it! He has come over here expressly to be with you, so I think you should give him every minute of your time. Men are fickle creatures, my dear! It will take some time yet to despoil them of the idea that women were made for their convenience."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I am afraid the man is not born yet for whose convenience I was made!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Well! you know the old saying: 'Most women can catch a man but it takes a clever woman to keep him.' I don't mean to insinuate that you are in any danger of losing Ralph, but I think he's quite worth keeping and, I believe you think so too!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And I mean to keep him!" replied Miss Leyton, as she went on writing.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Margaret did not venture to give her any further hints but returned to her own room and took another look through her spyglass.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The bathers in whom she was interested had returned to their machines by this time and presently emerged, "clothed and in their right minds."[100] Miss Brandt, looking more attractive than before with her long hair hanging down her back to dry. And then, that occurred which she had been anticipating. Captain Pullen, having taken a survey of the beach and seeing none of his own party there, climbed with Harriet Brandt to where they were high and dry above the tide and threw himself down on the hot, loose sand by her side, whilst the Baron and Baroness with a laughing injunction to the two young people to take care of themselves, toiled up to the Digue and walked off in another direction.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: When they all met at déjeuner, she attacked her brother-in-law on the subject.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Have you been bathing all this while?" she said to him, "you must have stayed very long in the water!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! dear no!" he replied, "I wasn't in above a quarter of an hour!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And what have you been doing since?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Strolling about looking for you and Elinor!" said Captain Pullen. Why the dickens didn't you come out this lovely morning?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I could not leave baby!" said Margaret shortly.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And I was writing," chimed in Elinor.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Very well, ladies, if you prefer your own company to mine, of course I have nothing to say against it! But I suppose you are not going to shut yourselves up this afternoon!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! no. It is a public duty to attend the Bataille des Fleurs. Have you bought any confetti, Ralph?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I have! Miss Brandt was good enough to shew me where to get them and we are well provided. There is to be a race between lady jockeys at the end of the Digue too, I perceive!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "What, with horses?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I conclude so. I see they have railed in a portion of ground for the purpose," replied Captain Pullen.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "'Ow could they race without 'orses?" called out the Baroness.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Harriet Brandt did not join in the conversation but she was gazing all the while at Ralph Pullen-not furtively as she had done the day before, but openly and unabashedly, as though she held a proprietary right in him. Margaret noticed her manner at once and interpreted it aright but Miss Leyton, true to her principles, never raised her eyes in her direction and ignored everything that came from that side of the table.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Mrs. Pullen was annoyed; she knew how angry Elinor would be if she intercepted any telegraphic communication between her lover and Miss Brandt; and she rose from the table as soon as possible in order to avert such a catastrophe. She had never considered her brother-in-law a very warm wooer and she fancied that his manner towards Miss Leyton was more indifferent than usual. She took one turn with them along the Digue to admire the flower-bedecked villas which were in full beauty and then returned to her nursery, glad of an excuse to leave them together and give Elinor a chance of becoming more cordial and affectionate to Ralph than she had yet appeared to be. The lovers had not been alone long, however, before they were waylaid, to the intense disgust of Elinor, by Harriet Brandt and her friend Olga Brimont.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Still further to her annoyance, Captain Pullen seemed almost to welcome the impertinent interference of the two girls, who could scarcely have had the audacity to join their company unless he had invited them to do so.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "The charettes are just about to start!" exclaimed Harriet, "O! they are lovely, and such dear little children! I am so glad that the Bataille des Fleurs takes place to-day because my friend's brother, Alfred Brimont, is coming to take her to Brussels the day after to-morrow!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Brussels is a jolly place. Mademoiselle Brimont will enjoy herself there," said Ralph. "There are theatres and balls and picture-galleries and every pleasure that a young lady's heart can desire!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Have you been to Brussels?" asked Harriet.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Yes! when I was a nasty little boy in jacket and trousers. I was placed at Mr. Jackson's English school there in order that I might learn French, but I'm afraid that was the last thing I acquired. The Jackson boys were known all over the town for the greatest nuisances in it!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "What did you do?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "What did we not do? We tore up and down the rue Montagne de la Cour at all hours of the day, shouting and screaming and getting into scrapes. We ran up bills at the shops which we had no money to pay-we appeared at every place of amusement-and we made love to all the school-girls till we had become a terror to the school-mistresses."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "What naughty boys!" remarked Miss Brandt, with a side-glance at Miss Leyton. She did not like to say all she thought before this very stiff and proper young English lady. "But Captain Pullen," she continued, "where are the confetti? Have you forgotten them? Shall I go and buy some more?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "No! no! my pockets are stuffed with them," he said, producing two bags, of which he handed Harriet one. Her thanks were conveyed by throwing a large handful of tiny pieces of blue and white and pink paper (which do duty for the more dangerous chalk sugarplums) at him and which covered his tweed suit and sprinkled his fair hair and moustaches. He returned the compliment by flying after her retreating figure and liberally showering confetti upon her.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! Ralph! I do hope you are not going to engage in this horseplay," exclaimed Elinor Leyton, "because if so I would rather return to the Hotel. Surely we may leave such vulgarities to the common people and-Miss Harriet Brandt!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "What nonsense!" he replied. "It's evident you've never been in Rome during the Carnival! Why everyone does it! It's the national custom. If you imagine I'm going to stand by, like a British tourist, and stare at everything without joining in the fun, you're very much mistaken!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But is it fun?" questioned Miss Leyton.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "To me it is! Here goes!" he cried, as he threw a handful of paper into the face of a passing stranger who gave him as good as she had got in return.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I call it low-positively vulgar," said Miss Leyton, "to behave so familiarly with people one has never seen before-of whose antecedents one knows nothing! I should be very much surprised if the mob behaved in such a manner towards me. Oh!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The exclamation was induced by the action of some young épicier, or hotel garçon, who threw a mass of confetti into her face with such violence as almost for the moment to blind her.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Ha! ha! ha!" roared Ralph Pullen with his healthy British lungs, as he saw her outraged feelings depicted in her countenance.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I thought you'd get it before long!" he said, as she attempted to brush the offending paper off her mantle.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "It has not altered my opinion of the indecency of the custom!" she replied.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Never mind!" he returned soothingly. "Here come the charettes."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: They were really a charming sight. On one cart was drawn a boat, with little children dressed as fishermen and women-another represented a harvest field, with the tiny haymakers and reapers-whilst a third was piled with wool to represent snow, on the top of which were seated three little girls attired as Esquimaux.[101] The mail-carts and perambulators belonging to the visitors to Heyst were also well represented and beautifully trimmed with flowers. The first prize was embowered in lilies and white roses, whilst its tiny inmate was seated in state as the Goddess Flora,[102] with a wreath twined in her golden curls. The second was taken by a gallant Neapolitan fisherman of about four years old, who wheeled a mail-cart of pink roses in which sat his little sisters, dressed as angels with large white wings. The third was a wheel barrow hidden in moss and narcissi, on which reposed a Sleeping Beauty robed in white tissue with a coronal of forget-me-nots.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Harriet Brandt fell into ecstasies over everything she saw. When pleased and surprised she expressed herself more like a child than a young woman and became extravagant and ungovernable. She tried to kiss each baby that took part in the procession, and thrust coins into their chubby hands to buy bonbons and confetti with. Captain Pullen thought her conduct most natural and unaffected; but Miss Leyton insisted that it was all put on for effect. Olga Brimont tried to put in a good word for her friend.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Harriet is very fond of children," she said, "but she has never seen any-there were no children at the Convent under ten years of age, so she does not know how to make enough of them when she meets them. She wants to kiss everyone. Some times, I tell her I think she would like to eat them. But she only means to be kind!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I am sure of that!" said Captain Pullen.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But she should be told," interposed Elinor, "that it is not the custom in civilized countries for strangers to kiss every child they meet, any more than it is to speak before being introduced, or to bestow their company where it is not desired. Miss Brandt has a great deal to learn in that respect before she can enter English Society!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: As is often the case when a woman becomes unjust in abusing another, Miss Leyton made Captain Pullen say more to cover her discourtesy than, in other circumstances, he would have done.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Miss Brandt," he said slowly, "is so beautiful that she will have a great deal forgiven her, that would not be overlooked in a plainer woman."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "That may be your opinion, but it is not mine," replied Miss Leyton.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Her tone was so acid that it sent him flying from her side to battle with his confetti against the tribe of Montagues who, fortunately for the peace of all parties, joined their forces to theirs and after some time spent on the Digue they returned, a large party, to the Hotel.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: It was not until they had sat down to dinner that they remembered they had never been to see the lady jockey race.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "He! he! he!" laughed Madame Gobelli, "but I did and you lost something, I can tell you! We 'ad great difficulty to get seats but when we did, it was worth it, wasn't it, Gustave?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "You said so, mein tear!" replied the Baron, gravely.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And you thought so, you old rascal! don't you tell me! I saw your wicked eyes glozing at the gals in their breeches and boots! There weren't any 'orses after all, Captain Pullen, but sixteen gals with different coloured jackets on and top boots and tight white breeches, such a sight you never saw, Gustave 'ere, did 'ave a treat! As for Bobby, when I found we couldn't get out again because of the crowd, I tied my 'andkerchief over 'is eyes, and made him put 'is 'ead in my lap!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Dear! dear!" cried Ralph, laughing, "was it as bad as that, Madame?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Bad! my dear boy! It was as bad as it could be! It's a mercy you weren't there or we shouldn't 'ave seen you 'ome again so soon! There were the sixteen gals with their tight breeches and their short racing jackets, and a fat fellow dressed like a huntsman whipping 'em round and round the ring as if they were so much cattle! You should 'ave seen them 'op when he touched 'em up with the lash of 'is whip. I expect they've never 'ad such a tingling since the time their mothers smacked 'em! There was a little fat one there! I wish you could 'ave seen 'er, when 'e whipped 'er to make 'er 'urry! It was comical! She 'opped like a kangaroo!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And what was the upshot of it all? Who won?" asked Ralph.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! I don't know! I got Gustave out as soon as I could! I wasn't going to let 'im spend the whole afternoon watching those gals 'opping. There were 'is eyes goggling out of 'is 'ead, and his lips licking each other as if 'e was sucking a sugar-stick-"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Mein tear! mein tear!" interposed the unfortunate Baron.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "You go on with your dinner, Gustave, and leave me alone! I saw you! And no more lady jockey races do you attend whilst we're in this Popish country. They ain't good for you."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I'm very thankful that I have been saved such a dangerous exper-iment," said Captain Pullen, "though if I thought that you would tie your handkerchief over my eyes and put my head in your lap, Madame, I should feel tempted to try it as soon as dinner is over!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Go along with you, you bad boy!" chuckled the Baroness, "there's something else to see this evening! They are going to 'ave a procession of lanterns as soon as it's dark!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And it is to stop in front of every hotel," added Harriet, "and the landlords are going to distribute bonbons and gateaux amongst the lantern bearers."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! we must not miss that on any account!" replied Captain Pullen, addressing himself to her in reply.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Margaret and Elinor thought, when the time came, that they should be able to see the procession of lanterns just as well from the balcony as when mingled with the crowd, so they brought their work and books down there and sat with Ralph, drinking coffee and conversing of all that had occurred. The Baroness had disappeared and Harriet Brandt had apparently gone with her-a fact for which both ladies were inwardly thankful.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Presently, as the dusk fell, the procession of lanterns could be seen wending its way from the further end of the Digue. It was a very pretty and fantastical sight. The bearers were not only children-many grown men and women took part in it and the devices into which the Chinese lanterns had been formed were quaint and clever. Some held a ring around them, as milkmaids carry their pails-others held crosses and banners designed in tiny lanterns, far above their heads. One, which could be seen topping all the rest, was poised like a skipping rope over the bearer's shoulders, whilst the coloured lanterns swung inside it like a row of bells. The members of the procession shouted, or sung, or danced, or walked steadily as suited their temperaments and came along, a merry crowd up and down the Digue, stopping at the various hotels for largesse in the shape of cakes and sugar-plums.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Ralph Pullen found his eyes wandering more than once in the direction of the Baroness's sitting-room to see if he could catch a glimpse of her or her protégée (as Harriet Brandt seemed now universally acknowledged to be), but he heard no sound, nor caught a glimpse of them, and concluded in consequence that they had left the hotel again.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Whoever is carrying that skipping rope of lanterns seems to be in a merry mood," observed Margaret after a while, "for it is jumping up and down in the most extravagant manner! She must be dancing! Do look, Elinor!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I see! I suppose this sort of childish performance amuses a childish people, but for my own part I think once of it is quite enough and am thankful that we are not called upon to admire it in England!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! I think it is rather interesting," remarked Margaret, "I only wish my dear baby had been well enough to enjoy it! How she would have screamed and cooed at those bright coloured lanterns! But when I tried to attract her attention to them just now she only whined to be put into her cot again. How thankful I shall be to see dear Doctor Phillips to-morrow!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The procession had reached the front of the Hotel by this time and halted there for refreshment. The waiters, Jules and Phillippe and Henri, appeared with plates of dessert and cakes and threw them indiscriminately amongst the people. One of the foremost to jump and scramble to catch the falling sweetmeats was the girl who carried the lantern skipping rope above her head and in whom Ralph Pullen, to his astonishment, recognised Harriet Brandt. There she was, fantastically dressed in a white frock and a broad yellow sash, with her magnificent hair loose and wreathed with scarlet flowers. She looked amazingly handsome, like a Bacchante, and her appearance and air of abandon sent the young man's blood into his face and up to the roots of his fair hair.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Surely!" exclaimed Margaret, "that is never Miss Brandt!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Yes! it is," cried Harriet, "I'm having the most awful fun! Why don't you come too? I've danced the whole way up the Digue, and it is so warm! I wish the waiters would give us something to drink! I've eaten so many bonbons I feel quite sick!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "What will you take, Miss Brandt?" asked Captain Pullen eagerly, "limonade or soda water?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "A limonade, please! You are good!" she replied, as he handed her the tumbler over the balcony balustrades. "Come along and dance with me!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I cannot! I am with my sister and Miss Leyton!" he replied.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! pray do not let us prevent you," said Elinor in her coldest voice, "Margaret was just going upstairs and I am quite ready to accompany her!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "No, no, Elinor," whispered Mrs. Pullen with a shake of her head, "stay here and keep Ralph company!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But it is nearly ten o'clock," replied Miss Leyton consulting her watch, "and I have been on my feet all day! and feel quite ready for bed. Good-night Ralph!" she continued, offering him her hand.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Well! if you two are really going to bed I shall go too," said Captain Pullen rising, "for there will be nothing for me to do here after you're gone!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Not even to follow the procession?" suggested Miss Leyton, with a smile.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Don't talk nonsense!" he rejoined crossly. "Am I the sort of man to go bobbing up and down the Digue amongst a parcel of children?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: He shook hands with them both and walked away rather sulkily to his own quarter of the hotel. But he did not go to bed. He waited until some fifteen minutes had elapsed and then telling himself that it was impossible to sleep at that hour, and that if Elinor chose to behave like a bear it was not his fault, he came downstairs again and sauntered out on the sea front.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: It was very lonely there at that moment. The procession had turned and gone down to the other end again, where its lights and banners could be seen waving about in the still summer air.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Why shouldn't the girl jump about and enjoy herself if she chooses," thought Ralph Pullen, "Elinor makes no allowances for condition or age, but would have every one as prim and old-maidish as herself. I declare she gets worse each time I see her! A nice sort of wife she will make if this kind of thing goes on! But by Jingo! if we are ever married I'll take her prudery out of her, and make her-what? The woman who commences by pursing her mouth up at everything ends by opening it wider than anybody else! There's twice as much harm in a prude as in one of these frank openhearted girls whose eyes tell you what they're thinking of the first time you see them!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: He had been strolling down the Digue as he pondered thus, and now found himself meeting the procession again.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Come and dance with me," cried Harriet Brandt who, apparently as fresh as ever, was still waving her branch of lanterns to the measure of her steps. He took her hand and tried to stop her.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Haven't you had about enough of this?" he said, "I'm sure you must be tired. Here's a little boy without a lantern! Give him yours to hold and come for a little walk with me!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The touch of his cool hand upon her heated palm seemed to rouse all the animal in Harriet Brandt's blood. Her hand, very slight and lissom, clung to his with a force of which he had not thought it capable and he felt it trembling in his clasp.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Come!" he repeated coaxingly, "you mustn't dance any more or you will overtire yourself! Come with me and get cool and rest!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: She threw her branch of lanterns to the boy beside her impetuously.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Here!" she cried, "take them! I don't want them any more! And take me away," she continued to Ralph, but without letting go of his hand, "You are right! I want-I want-rest!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Her slight figure swayed towards him as he led her out of the crowd and across a narrow street to where the road ran behind all the houses and hotels and was dark and empty and void. The din of the voices, and the trampling of feet, and the echo of the songs still reached them, but they could see nothing-the world was on the Digue and they were in the dusk and quietude together-and alone.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Ralph felt the slight form beside him lean upon his shoulder till their faces almost touched. He threw his arm about her waist. Her hot breath fanned his cheek.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Kiss me!" she murmured in a dreamy voice. Captain Pullen was not slow to accept the invitation so confidingly extended. What Englishman would be? He turned his face to Harriet Brandt's, and her full red lips met his own in a long-drawn kiss that seemed to sap his vitality. As he raised his head again he felt faint and sick, but quickly recovering himself he gave her a second kiss more passionate, if possible, than the first. Then the following whispered conversation ensued between them. "Do you know," he commenced, with his head close to hers, "that you are the very jolliest little girl that I have ever met!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And you-you are the man I have dreamt of, but never seen till now!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "How is that? Am I so different from the rest of my sex?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Very-very different! So strong and brave and beautiful!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Dear little girl! And so you really like me?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I love you," said Harriet feverishly, "I loved you the first minute we met."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And I love you! You're awfully sweet and pretty, you know!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Do you really think so? What would Mrs. Pullen say if she heard you?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Mrs. Pullen is not the keeper of my conscience. But she must not hear it."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! no! nor Miss Leyton either!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Most certainly not Miss Leyton. She is a terrible prude! She would be awfully shocked!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "It must be a secret,-just between you and me!" murmured the girl. "Just so! A sweet little secret, all our own, and nobody else's!" And then the fair head and the dark one came again in juxtaposition, and the rest was lost in-Silence!
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: - CHAPTER VII -
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Doctor Phillips had not been in the Htel Lion d'Or five minutes before Margaret Pullen took him upstairs to see her baby. She was becoming terribly anxious about her. They encountered Captain Ralph Pullen on the staircase.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Hullo! young man, and what have you been doing to yourself?" exclaimed the doctor.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: He was certainly looking ill. His face was chalky white, and his eyes seemed to have lost their brightness and colour.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Been up racketting late at night?" continued Doctor Phillips. "What is Miss Leyton about, not to look after you better?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "No, indeed, Doctor," replied the young man with a smile, "I am sure my sister-in-law will testify to the good hours I have kept since here. But I have a headache this morning-a rather bad one," he added, with his hand to the nape of his neck.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Perhaps this place doesn't agree with you-it was always rather famous for its smells if I remember aright! However, I am going to see Miss Ethel Pullen now and when I have finished with her I will look after you!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "No thank you, Doctor," said Ralph laughing, as he descended the stairs. "None of your nostrums for me! Keep them for the baby!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "He is not looking well," observed Doctor Phillips to Margaret, as they walked on together.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I don't think he is, now you point it out to me, but I have not noticed it before," replied Margaret. "I am sure he has been living quietly enough whilst here!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The infant was lying as she had now done for several days past- quite tranquil and free from pain but inert and half asleep. The doctor raised her eyelids and examined her eyeballs-felt her pulse and listened to her heart-but he did not seem to be satisfied.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "What has this child been having?" he asked abruptly.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Having, Doctor? Why! nothing of course, but her milk, and I have always that from the same cow!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "No opium-no soothing syrup, nor quackeries of any kind?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Certainly not! You know how often you have warned me against anything of the sort!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And no one has had the charge of her except you and the nurse here? You can both swear she has never been tampered with?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! I think so, certainly, yes! Baby has never been from under the eye of one or the other of us. A young lady resident in the hotel-a Miss Brandt-has often nursed her and played with her but one of us has always been there at the time."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "A Miss-what did you say?" demanded the doctor sharply.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "A Miss Brandt-a very good-natured girl, who is fond of children!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Very well then! I will go at once to the pharmacien's and get a prescription made up for your baby, and I hope that your anxiety may soon be relieved!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! thank you, Doctor, so much!" exclaimed Margaret. "I knew you would do her good as soon as you saw her!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: But the doctor was not so sure of himself. He turned the case over and over in his mind as he walked to the chemist's shop wondering how such a state of exhaustion and collapse could have been brought about.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The baby had her first dose and the doctor had just time to wash and change his travelling suit before they all met at the dinner table.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Here they found the party opposite augmented by the arrival of Monsieur Alfred Brimont, a young Brussels tradesman who had come over to Heyst to conduct his sister home. He was trying to persuade Harriet Brandt to accompany Olga and stay a few days with them but the girl-with a long look in the direction of Captain Pullen-shook her head determinately.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! you might come, Harriet, just for a few days," argued Olga, "now that the Bataille des Fleurs is over there is nothing left to stay for in Heyst, and Alfred says that Brussels is such a beautiful place."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "There are the theatres, and the Parc, and the Quinçonce, and Wauxhall!" said young Brimont persuasively, "Mademoiselle would enjoy herself, I have no doubt!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: But Harriet still negatived the proposal.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Why shouldn't we make up a party and all go together," suggested the Baroness. "Me and the Baron and Bobby and 'Arriet? You would like it then, my dear, wouldn't you?" she said to the girl, "and you really should see Brussels before we go 'ome! What do you say, Gustave? We'd go to the Hotel de Saxe, and see everything! It wouldn't take us more than a week or ten days."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Do as you like, mein tear," acquiesced the Baron.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And why shouldn't you come with us, Captain?" continued Madame Gobelli to Ralph. "You don't look quite the thing to me! A little change would do you good. All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy! 'Ave you been to Brussels?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I lived there for years, Madame, and know every part of it!" he replied.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Come and renew your acquaintance then, and take me and 'Arriet about! The Baron isn't much good when it comes to sightseeing, are you, Gustave? 'E likes 'is pipe and 'is slippers too well! But you're young and spry! Well! is it a bargain?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I really could not decide in such a hurry," said Ralph, with a glance at Margaret and Elinor, "but we might all go to Brussels perhaps, a little later on."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I don't think you must buoy up the hopes of the Baroness and Miss Brandt with that idea," remarked Miss Leyton coldly, "because I am sure that Mrs. Pullen has no intention of doing anything of the sort. If you wish to accompany Madame Gobelli's party you had better make your arrangements without any reference to us!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "All right! If you prefer it, I will," he answered in the same indifferent tone.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Who is that young lady sitting opposite with the dark eyes?" demanded Doctor Phillips of Mrs. Pullen.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "The same I spoke to you of upstairs as having been kind to baby-Miss Harriet Brandt!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I knew a Brandt once," he answered. "Has she anything to do with the West Indies?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! yes! she comes from Jamaica! She is an orphan, the daughter of Doctor Henry Brandt, and has been educated in the Ursuline Convent there! She is a young lady with an independent fortune and considered to be quite a catch in Heyst!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And you and Miss Leyton are intimate with her?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "She has attached herself very much to us since coming here. She has few friends, poor girl!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Will you introduce me?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Miss Brandt, my friend, Doctor Phillips, wishes for an introduction to you."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The usual courtesies passed between them and then the doctor said,
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I fancy I knew your father, Miss Brandt, when I was quartered in Jamaica with the Thirteenth Lances. Did he not live on the top of the Hill, on a plantation called Helvetia?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "That was the name of our place," replied Harriet, "but I left it when I was only eleven. My trustee Mr. Trawler lives there now!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Ah! Trawler the attorney! I have no doubt he made as much out of the property as he could squeeze."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Do you mean that he cheated me?" asked Harriet, naïvely.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "God forbid! my dear young lady. But he was a great crony of your father's, and a d-d sharp lawyer, and those sort of gentry generally feather their own nest pretty well, in payment of their friendship."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "He can't do me any harm now," said Harriet, "for I have my property in my own hands!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Quite right! quite right! that is, if you're a business woman," rejoined the doctor. "And are you travelling all by yourself ?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Harriet was about to answer in the affirmative when the Baroness took the words out of her mouth.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "No, Sir, she ain't! She came over with her friend, Mademoiselle Brimont, and now she's under my chaperonage. She's a deal too 'andsome, ain't she? to be travelling about the world alone with her money-bags under her arm. My name's the Baroness Gobelli,- this is my 'usband, Baron Gustave Gobelli, and this is my little boy, Bobby Bates-by my first 'usband you'll understand-and when you return to London, if you like to come and see Miss Brandt at our 'ouse-the Red 'Ouse, 'Olloway, we shall be very pleased to see you!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I am sure, Madame, you are infinitely kind," replied Doctor Phillips gravely.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Not at all! You'll meet no end of swells there, Prince Loris of Taxelmein, and Prince Adalbert of Waxsquiemer, and 'eaps of others. But all the same we're in trade, the Baron and I-and we're not ashamed of it either. We make boots and shoes! Our firm is Fantaisie et Cie, of Oxford Street and though I say it, you won't find better boots and shoes in all London than ours. No brown paper soles and rotten uppers! Not a bit of it! It's all genuine stuff with us. You can take any boot out of the shop and rip it to pieces and prove what I say! The best materials and the best workmen, that's our principle, and it answers. We can't make 'em fast enough!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I have no doubt of it," again, gravely, responded the old doctor.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Ah! you might send some of your patients to us, Doctor, and we'll pay back by recommending you to our friends. Are you a Gout man? Prince Adalbert 'as the gout awfully! I've rubbed 'is feet with Elliman's Embrocation,[103] by the hour together but nothing gives 'im relief! Now if you could cure 'im your fortune would be made! 'E says it's all the English climate, but I say it's over eating and 'e'd attend more to a medical man if 'e told 'im to diet than 'e will to me!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Doubtless, doubtless!" said the Doctor, in a dreamy manner. He seemed to be lost in a reverie and Margaret had to touch his arm to remind him that the meal was concluded.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: She wanted him to join the others in a promenade and see the beauties of Heyst but he was strangely eager in declining it.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "No! no! let the youngsters go and enjoy themselves, but I want to speak to you, alone."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "My dear doctor, you frighten me! Nothing about baby, I hope!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Not at all! Don't be foolish! But I want to talk to you where we cannot be overheard."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I think we had better wait till the rest have dispersed then, and go down upon the sands. It is almost impossible to be private in a hotel like this!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "All right! Get your hat and we will stroll off together."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: As soon as they were out of earshot he commenced abruptly, "It is about that Miss Brandt! You seem pretty intimate with her! You must stop it at once. You must have nothing more to do with her."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Margaret's eyes opened wide with distress.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But, Doctor Phillips, for what reason? I don't see how we could give her up now unless we leave the place."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Then leave the place! You mustn't know her, neither must Miss Leyton. She comes of a terrible parentage. No good can ever ensue of association with her."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "You must tell me more than this, Doctor, if you wish me to follow your advice!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I will tell you all I know myself! Some twelve or thirteen years ago I was quartered in medical charge of the Thirteenth Lances and stationed in Jamaica where I knew of, rather than knew, the father of this girl, Henry Brandt. You called him a doctor-he was not worthy of the name. He was a scientist perhaps-a murderer certainly!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "How horrible! Do you really mean it?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Listen to me! This man Brandt matriculated in the Swiss hospitals, whence he was expelled for having caused the death of more than one patient by trying his scientific experiments upon them. The Swiss laboratories are renowned for being the most foremost in Vivisection and other branches of science that gratify the curiosity and harden the heart of man more than they confer any lasting benefit on humanity. Even there Henry Brandt's barbarity was considered to render him unfit for association with civilized practitioners, and he was expelled with ignominy. Having a private fortune he settled in Jamaica and set up his laboratory there, and I would not shock your ears by detailing one hundredth part of the atrocities that were said to take place under his supervision and in company of this man Trawler, whom the girl calls her trustee, and who is one of the greatest brutes unhung."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Are you not a little prejudiced, dear Doctor?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Not at all! If, when you have heard all, you still say so, you are not the woman I have taken you for. Brandt did not confine his scientific investigations to the poor dumb creation. He was known to have decoyed natives into his Pandemonium[104] who were never heard of again which, raised at last, the public feeling so much against him that, I am glad to say, his negroes revolted and, after having murdered him with appropriate atrocity, set fire to his house and burned it and all his property to the ground. Don't look so shocked! I repeat that I am glad to say it, for he richly deserved his fate, and no torture could be too severe for one who spent his worthless life in torturing God's helpless animals!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And his wife-" commenced Margaret.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "He had no wife! He was never married!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Never married! But this girl Harriet Brandt-"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Has no more right to the name than you have! Henry Brandt was not the man to regard the laws, either of God or man. There was no reason why he should not have married-for that very cause, I suppose, he preferred to live in concubinage."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Poor Harriet! Poor child! And her mother, did you know her?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Don't speak to me of her mother. She was not a woman she was a fiend, a fitting match for Henry Brandt! To my mind she was a revolting creature. A fat, flabby half caste who hardly ever moved out of her chair but sat eating all day long until the power to move had almost left her! I can see her now with her sensual mouth, her greedy eyes, her low forehead and half-formed brain, and her lust for blood. It was said that the only thing which made her laugh was to watch the dying agonies of the poor creatures her brutal protector slaughtered. But she thirsted for blood, she loved the sight and smell of it, she would taste it on the tip of her finger when it came in her way. Her servants had some story amongst themselves to account for this lust. They declared that when her slave mother was pregnant with her she was bitten by a Vampire bat, which are formidable creatures in the West Indies and are said to fan their victims to sleep with their enormous wings whilst they suck their blood. Anyway the slave woman did not survive her delivery and her fellows prophecied that the child would grow up to be a murderess. Which doubtless she was in heart, if not in deed!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "What an awful description! And what became of her?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "She was killed at the same time as Brandt. Indeed the natives would have killed her in preference to him had they been obliged to choose, for they attributed all the atrocities that went on in the laboratory to her influence. They said she was 'Obeah', which means diabolical witchcraft in their language. And doubtless their unfortunate child would have been slaughtered also, had not the overseer of the plantation carried her off to his cabin and afterwards, when the disturbance was quelled, to the Convent where, you say, she has been educated."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But terrible as all this is, dear Doctor, it is not the poor girl's fault. Why should we give up her acquaintance for that?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "My dear Margaret, are you so ignorant as not to see that a child born under such conditions cannot turn out well? The bastard of a man like Henry Brandt, cruel, dastardly, godless, and a woman like her terrible mother, a sensual, self-loving, crafty and bloodthirsty half-caste-what do you expect their daughter to become? She may seem harmless enough at present, so does the tiger cub as it suckles its dam, but that which is bred in her will come out sooner or later and curse those with whom she may be associated. I beg and pray of you, Margaret, not to let that girl come near you or your child any more. There is a curse upon her and it will affect all within her influence!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "You have made me feel very uncomfortable, Doctor," replied Mrs. Pullen. "Of course if I had known all this previously I would not have cultivated Miss Brandt's acquaintance, and now I shall take your advice and drop her as soon as possible! There will be no difficulty with Miss Leyton, for she has had a strange dislike to the girl ever since we met, but she has certainly been very kind to my baby-"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "For Heaven's sake don't let her come near your baby any more!" cried Doctor Phillips, quickly.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Certainly I will not, and perhaps it would be as well if we moved on to Ostende or Blankenburghe, as we have sometimes talked of doing. It would sever the acquaintance in the most effectual way!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "By all means do so, particularly if the young lady does not go to Brussels, as that stout party was proposing at dinner time. What an extraordinary person she appears to be! Quite a character!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "That is just what she is! But, Doctor, there is another thing I should like to speak to you about concerning Miss Brandt, and I am sure I may trust you to receive it in the strictest confidence. It is regarding my brother-in-law, Ralph Pullen. I am rather afraid, from one or two things I have observed, that he likes Miss Brandt-O! I don't mean anything particular, for (as you know) he is engaged to be married to Elinor Leyton and I don't suspect him of wronging her, only-young men are rather headstrong you know and fond of their own way, and perhaps if you were to speak to Ralph-"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Tell me plainly, has he been carrying on with this girl?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Not in the sense you would take it, Doctor, but he affects her company and that of the Gobellis a good deal. Miss Brandt sings beautifully and Ralph loves music, but his action annoys Elinor, I can see that, and since you think we should break off the intimacy--"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I consider it most imperatively necessary, for many reasons, and especially in the case of a susceptible young man like Captain Pullen. She has money you say-"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Fifteen hundred a year! So I am told!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And Miss Leyton has nothing, and Ralph only his pay! O! yes! you are quite right, such an acquaintanceship is dangerous for him. The sense of honour is not so strong now as it was when I was a boy, and gold is a powerful bait with the rising generation. I will take an early opportunity of talking to Captain Pullen on the subject."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "You will not wound his feelings, Doctor, nor betray me?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Trust me for doing neither! I shall speak from my own experience, as I have done to you. If he will not take my advice you must get some one with more influence to caution him about it. I hardly know how to make my meaning clear to you, Margaret, but Miss Brandt is a dangerous acquaintance for all of you. We medical men know the consequences of heredity better than outsiders can do. A woman born in such circumstances-bred of sensuality, cruelty, and heartlessness-cannot, in the order of things, be modest, kind, or sympathetic. And she probably carries unknown dangers in her train. Whatever her fascinations or her position may be, I beg of you to drop her at once and for ever!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Of course I will, but it seems hard upon her! She has seemed to crave so for affection and companionship."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "As her mother craved for food and blood; as her father craved for inflicting needless agony on innocent creatures and sneered meanwhile at their sufferings! I am afraid I should have little faith in Miss Brandt craving for anything except the gratification of her own senses!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: They were seated on the lower step of the wooden flight that led from the Digue to the sands so that, whilst they could see what went on above them, they were concealed from view themselves.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Just then Harriet Brandt's beautiful voice, accompanied by the silvery strains of the mandoline, was heard to warble Gounod's "Marguerite"[105] from the open window of the Baroness's sitting-room. Margaret glanced up. The apartment was brilliantly lighted-on the table were bottles of wine and spirits, with cakes and fruit, and Madame Gobelli's bulky form might be seen leaning over the dishes. She had assembled quite a little party there that night. The two Brimonts were present, and Captain Pullen's tall figure was distinctly visible under the lamplight. Harriet was seated on the sofa and her full voice filled the atmosphere with melody.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "There's something like a voice!" remarked the old doctor.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "That is the very girl we have been talking of!" replied Mrs. Pullen. "I told you she had a lovely voice and was an accomplished musician."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Is that so?" said Doctor Phillips, "then she is still more dangerous than I imagined her to be! Those tones would be enough to drag any man down to perdition, especially if accompanied by such a nature as I cannot but believe she must have inherited from her progenitors!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And see, Doctor, there is Ralph," continued Margaret, pointing out her brother-in-law. "I left him with Miss Leyton. He must have got rid of her by some means and crept up to the Gobellis. He cannot care for them. He is so refined, so fastidious with regard to people in general that a woman like the Baroness must grate upon his feelings every time she opens her mouth, and the Baron never opens his at all. He can only frequent their company for the sake of Harriet Brandt! I have seen it for some time past and it has made me very uneasy."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "He shall know everything about her to-morrow and then if he will not hear reason-" Doctor Phillips shrugged his shoulders and said no more.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But surely," said his companion, "you do not think for a moment that Ralph could ever seriously contemplate breaking his engagement with Elinor Leyton for the sake of this girl! O! how angry Arthur would be if he suspected his brother could be guilty of such a thing-he, who considers that a man's word should be his bond!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "It is impossible to say, Margaret-I should not like to give an opinion on the subject. When young men are led away by their passions they lose sight of everything else-and if this girl is anything like her mother she must be an epitome of lust!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! you will speak to Ralph as soon as ever you can," cried Margaret, in a tone of distress. "You will put the matter as strongly before him as possible, will you not?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "You may depend on my doing all I can, Margaret, but as there seems no likelihood of my being able to interview the young gentleman to-night, suppose you and I go to bed! I feel rather tired after my passage over and you must want to go back to your baby!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Doctor," said Margaret, in a timid voice, as they ascended the hotel stair-case together, "you don't think baby very ill, do you?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I think she requires a great deal of care, Margaret!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But she has always had that!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I don't doubt it, but I can't deny that there are symptoms about her case that I do not understand. She seems to have had all her strength drawn out of her. She is in the condition of a child who has been exercised and excited and hurried from place to place, far beyond what she is able to bear. But it may arise from internal causes. I shall be better able to judge to-morrow when my medicine has had its effect. Good-night, my dear, and don't worry. Please God, we will have the little one all right again in a couple of days."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: But he only said the words out of compassion. In his own opinion the infant was dying.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Meanwhile Harriet, having finished her songs, was leaning out of the window with Ralph Pullen by her side. She wore an open sleeve and as he placed his hand upon her bare arm the girl thrilled from head to foot
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And so you are determined not to go to Brussels," he whispered in her ear.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Why should I go? You will not be there! The Baroness wants to stay for a week! What would become of me all that time, moping after you?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Are you sure that you would mope? Monsieur Brimont is a nice young man and seems quite ready to throw himself at your feet! Would he not do as well, pro tem?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Harriet's only answer was to cast her large eyes upwards to meet his own.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Does that mean, 'No'," continued Captain Pullen. "Then how would it do if I joined you there after a couple of days? Would the Baroness be complaisant do you think, and a little short sighted, and let us go about together and shew each other the sights of the town?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! I'm sure she would!" cried Harriet, all the blood in her body flying into her face, "she is so very kind to me! Madame Gobelli!" she continued, turning from the window to the light, "Captain Pullen says that if you will allow him to shew us the lions of Brussels, he will come and join us there in a couple of days-"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "If I find I can manage it!" interposed Ralph, cautiously.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Manage it! Why, of course you can manage it," said the Baroness. "What's to 'inder a young man like you doing as 'e chooses? You're not tied to your sister's apron-string, are you? Now mind! we shall 'old you to it, for I believe it's the only thing that will make 'Arriet come, and I think a week in Brussels will do us all good! You're not looking well yourself you know, Captain Pullen! You're as white as ashes this evening, and if I didn't know you were such a good boy I should say you'd been dissipating a bit lately! He! he! he!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "The only dissipation I have indulged in is basking in the sunshine of your eyes, Madame!" replied Ralph gallantly.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "That's a good 'un!" retorted the Baroness, "it is more likely you've been looking too much in the eyes of my little friend 'ere. You're a couple of foxes, that's what you are, and I expect it would take all my time to be looking after you both! And so I suppose it's settled, Miss 'Arriet, and you'll come with us to Brussels after all!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Yes, Madame, if you'll take charge of me!" said Miss Brandt.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "We'll do that for a couple of days and then we'll give over charge. Are we to engage a room for you, Captain, at the Htel de Saxe?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I had better see after that myself, Madame, as the date of my coming is uncertain," replied Ralph.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "But you will come!" whispered Harriet.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Need you ask? Would I not run over the whole world only to find myself by your side? Haven't you taken the taste out of everything else for me, Harriet?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: - CHAPTER VIII -
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Doctor Phillips was a man of sixty and a bachelor. He had never made any home ties for himself, and was therefore more inter-ested in Margaret Pullen (whose father had been one of his dearest friends) than he might otherwise have been. He feared that a heavy trial lay before her and he was unwilling to see it aggravated by any misconduct on the part of her brother-in-law. He could see that the young man was (to say the least of it) not behaving fairly towards his fiancée, Elinor Leyton, and he was determined to open his eyes to the true state of affairs with regard to Harriet Brandt. He spent a sleepless night, his last visit to Margaret's suffering child having strengthened his opinion as to her hopeless condition, and he lay awake wondering how he should break the news to the poor young mother. He rose with the intention of speaking to Ralph without delay, but he found it more difficult to get a word with him than he had anticipated. The Gobelli party had decided to start with the Brimonts that afternoon and Captain Pullen stuck to them the entire morning, ostensibly to assist the Baroness in her preparations for departure, but in reality, as anyone could see, to linger by the side of Miss Brandt. Miss Leyton perceived her lover's defalcation as plainly as the rest but she was too proud to make a hint upon the subject, even to Margaret Pullen. She sat alone in the balcony, reading a book, and gave no sign of annoyance or discomfiture. But a close observer might have seen the trembling of her lip when she attempted to speak, and the fixed, white look upon her face which betrayed her inward anxiety. It made Margaret's kind heart ache to see her, and Doctor Phillips more indignant with Ralph Pullen than before.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: The party for Brussels had arranged to travel by the three o'clock train and at the appointed time the doctor was ready in the balcony to accompany them to the entrept. There were no cabs in Heyst, the station being in the town. Luggage was conveyed backwards and forwards in handcarts drawn by the porters, and travellers invariably walked to their destination. The Baroness appeared dressed for her journey in an amazing gown of blue velvet trimmed with rare Maltese lace, with a heavy mantle over it and a small hat on her head which made her round, flat, unmeaning face, look coarser than before. She used the Herr Baron as a walking stick as usual whilst Harriet Brandt, in a white frock and large hat shading her glowing eyes under a scarlet parasol, looked like a tropical bird skimming by her side, with Captain Pullen in close attendance carrying a flimsy wrap in case she should require it before she reached her journey's end. The Brimonts, following in the rear, were of no account beside their more brilliant and important friends.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Ralph Pullen did not look pleased when he saw Doctor Phillips join the party.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Are you also going to the entrept?" he exclaimed, "what can you find to interest you there?-a dirty little smutty place! I am going just to help the ladies over the line as there is no bridge for crossing."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Perhaps I am bent on the same errand," replied the doctor, "do you give me credit for less gallantry than yourself, Pullen?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "That's right, Doctor," said the Baroness, "and I've no doubt you'll be very useful! My Bobby ain't any manner of good, and the Baron 'as so many traps to carry that 'e 'asn't got an arm to spare. I only wish you were coming with us! Why don't you make up your mind to come over with Captain Pullen the day after to-morrow, and 'ave a little 'oliday?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I was not aware that Captain Pullen was going to Brussels, Madame! I fancy he will have to get Miss Leyton's consent first!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: At the mention of Miss Leyton's name in connection with himself Ralph Pullen flushed uneasily and Harriet Brandt turned a look of startled enquiry upon the speaker.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! 'ang Miss Leyton!" retorted the Baroness, graphically, "she surely wouldn't stop Captain Pullen's fun just because 'e's staying with 'is sister-in-law! I should call that very 'ard. You can't always tie a young man to 'is relations' apron-strings, Doctor!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Not always, Madame!" he replied, and dropped the subject.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "You wouldn't let Miss Leyton or Mrs. Pullen keep you from me!" whispered Harriet to her cavalier.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Never!" he answered emphatically.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: They had reached the little station by this time and the porters were calling out vociferously that the train was about to start for Brussels, so that in the hurry of procuring their tickets and conveying the ladies and the luggage across the cinder-besprinkled line to where the train stood puffing to be off, there was no more time to exchange sentimentalities or excite suspicion. The party being safely stowed away in their carriage, Ralph Pullen and Doctor Phillips stood on the wooden platform with their hats off, bowing their farewells.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Mind you don't put off your coming after Thursday!" screamed the Baroness to Ralph, as she filled up the entire window with her bulky person, "we shall expect you by dinner-time! And I shall bespeak a room for you, whether you will or no! 'Arriet 'ere will break 'er 'eart if you don't turn up and I don't want the responsibility of 'er committing suicide on my 'ands!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "All right! all right!" responded Ralph, pretending to turn it off as a joke. "None of you shall do that on my account, I promise you!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "O! well! I 'ope you're going to keep your word, or we shall come back to 'Eyst in double quick time. Good-bye! Good-bye!" and kissing her fat hand to the two gentlemen, the Baroness was whisked out of Heyst.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Ralph looked longingly after the departing line of carriages for a minute, and then crossed the line again to the road beyond.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: Doctor Phillips did not say a word till they were well clear of the station and then he commenced,
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Of course you're not in earnest about following these people to Brussels."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Why should I not be? I knew Brussels well as a lad and I should enjoy renewing my acquaintance with the old town."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "In proper company perhaps, but you can hardly call that party a fit one for you to associate with!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "You're alluding to the Baron and Baroness being in trade. Well! as a rule I confess that I do not care to associate intimately with boot-makers and their friends, but one does things abroad that one would not dream of doing in England. And for all her vulgarity, Madame Gobelli is very good-natured and generous, and I really don't see that I lower my dignity by being on friendly terms with her whilst here!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I was not alluding to Madame Gobelli, though I do not think that either she or the Brimonts are fit companions for a man who belongs to the Limerick Rangers, and is engaged to marry the daughter of Lord Walthamstowe. Neither do I admire the spirit which would induce you to hobnob with them in Heyst when you would cut them in Bond Street. But as far as I know the Baron and his wife are harmless. It is Miss Harriet Brandt that I would caution you against!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: A quick resentment appeared on Ralph Pullen's features. His eyes darkened and an ominous wrinkle stood out on his brow.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "And what may you have to say of Miss Brandt?" he demanded, coldly.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "A great deal more than you know or can possibly imagine! She is not a fit person for Elinor Leyton to associate with, and consequently, one whom it is your duty to avoid instead of cultivating."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I think you exceed your duty, Doctor, in speaking to me thus!"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I am sorry you should think so, Pullen, but your anger will not deter me from telling you what is in my mind. You must not forget how old a friend I am of both sides of your family. Your brother Arthur is one of my greatest chums, and his wife's father was, without exception, my dearest friend-added to this, I am on intimate terms with the Waltham-stowes. Knowing what I do, therefore, I should hold myself criminal if I left you in ignorance of the truth concerning this young woman."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Are you alluding, may I ask, to Miss Brandt?"
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "I am alluding to the girl who calls herself by that name but who is in reality only the bastard daughter of Henry Brandt, one of the most infamous men whom God ever permitted to desecrate this earth, and his half-caste mistress."
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "Be careful what you say, Doctor Phillips!" said Ralph Pullen, with ill-suppressed wrath gleaming in his blue eyes.
author: Marryat, Florence
title: The Blood of the Vampire

text: "There is no need to be, my dear fellow. I can verify everything I say, and I fear no man's resentment. I was stationed in Jamaica with my regiment some fifteen years ago when this girl was a child of six years old, running half naked about her father's plantation, uncared for by either parent and associating solely with the negro servants. Brandt was a brute-the perpetrator of such atrocities in vivisection and other scientific experiments that he was finally slaughtered on his own plantation by his servants, and everyone said it served him right. The mother was the most awful woman I have ever seen, and my experience of the sex in back slums and alleys has not been small. She was the daughter of a certain Judge Carey of Barbadoes by one of his slave girls and Brandt took her as his mistress before she was fourteen. At thirty, when I saw her, she was a revolting spectacle. Gluttonous and obese-her large eyes rolling and her sensual lips protruding as if she were always licking them in anticipation of her prey.
